question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
To compose a morose epicedium
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium.
question_list.question: How can one brighten one's torpor and tedium?
alternate_answers:
The limerick suggests that composing a morose epicedium (a funeral song or poem) can help brighten one's torpor and tedium. The limerick states:

"To compose a morose epicedium 
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium."

So the answer is that writing a moderately melancholy funeral poem or song can help alleviate boredom and listlessness, according to the limerick.

Compose a morose epicedium.
Craft a sad dirge, not too mournful,
Just medium, not scornful,
To lift your spirits, a musical medium.

question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
That damn call button jockey, room 9,
Is a pain in the base of my spine.
For no reason he rings
About minuscule things.
His sole purpose? To hear himself whine.
question_list.question: What is the sole purpose of the occupant of room 9?
alternate_answers: The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to repeatedly press the call button, which can be quite frustrating for others.
The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to ring the call button for no significant reason, mainly to hear himself whine.

question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
Mr. Thistle, what's this all about?
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!
question_list.question: Does Mr. Thistle follow our rules?
alternate_answers: Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules consistently. He often disregards them without explanation or justification.

Based on the limericks provided, the question appears to be about the limerick that mentions "Mr. Thistle". The relevant limerick is:

"Mr. Thistle, what's this all about? 
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!"

This limerick suggests that Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules, as the speaker is blowing the whistle on him for dismissing and flouting the rules.

question_list.author: Richard English
question_list.text:
Some folks might think cranberry glass
Is for fruit of the cranberry class.
But it's glass of deep red,
With a gold sheen, and said
To be sought by the English top brass.
question_list.question: What is sought by the English top brass?

question_list.author: Celia Warren
question_list.text:
Oh, don't throw your toys out your pram!
Yes, I treat all your emails as spam.
Hurt your feelings? Don't care;
I don't like you, so there!
Just accept that I don't give a damn!
question_list.question: Why do I treat all your emails as spam?
alternate_answers:
Because I don't like you, so there!
Your feelings? I don't really care.
Just accept that I'm cold,
And your messages, old,
Are as welcome as a grizzly bear.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The Chumash I'll try to describe:
They're a west Californian tribe
Who could sail the Pacific.
Their rock art's terrific,
And their name has a biblical vibe.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
Max Baer was a boxer (and clown)
Who once held the heavyweight crown.
Then-champ Primo Carnera
Was one in that era
Who took his big punch, then went down.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
This steep wooded valley has been
A two-mile-long ribbon of green
Since Lord Armstrong donated
(And largely created)
Newcastle's sublime Jesmond  Dene.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Sam Clemens—his pen name: Mark Twain—
Had a style that was folksy and plain,
But his Tom, Huck, and Jim
Have lived long after him;
In our hearts they will always remain.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
While carbon is handy for dating,
The answers add fuel to debating,
For skeptics make merry
When isotopes vary
For any cause other than waiting.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"Are you sexually active with Brooke?
Are you using protection?"  It took
About two or three more
Of these questions before
I screamed, "Look!  Are you writing a book?!"

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
It's the stubbornest mare that I've met
And as set in its ways as they get,
But it's slick with a trick
Called the hind-legged kick
And I'll get a curvet from it yet.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
I spotted my oldest friend Abe. He
Was gardening, and so I called, "Maybe
You don't like benzoin?"
"It's crabgrass I'm hoein'.
It's about all the benjamins, baby."

limerick_list.author: David Bourke
limerick_list.text:
The ambrosia beetle eats fungus.
(The amount they consume is humungous!)
You might think that they would
Have preferred some rice pud,
But none do, of (at least) those among us.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Endometrial hyperplasia: that
Is what women might get who are fat.
"Tell me, does it cause cancer?"
"Oh yes", is the answer,
"Though not always, and not off the bat".

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
While explaining a logical tenet,
In a dennet, he drove to the Senate,
Where they honored this brilliant,
And also resilient,
Philosopher, Daniel C. Dennett.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
It's been many a day and a night
Since dainty meant "joy" or "delight."
This sentence I saw, sir,
From the era of Chaucer:
Gret deyntee have we that he write.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
In his resumé, Senator Bill
Mentions Princeton and Capitol Hill.
Between them he passes
Through Rhodes-scholar'd classes.
The Knicks? They're played down, if you will.

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
Abiogenesis (1)
Says that maggots are bred by the sun.
Contrast this with (2)
The Darwinian view
That from matter all life has begun.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Hattie Caraway, lady long gone,
Was the first woman senator. On
Occasions the urge
Came to tinkle or purge.
She was faced with this snag: Where's the john?

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
What's used to make polymers (plastic)
More flexible, soft, and elastic?
An acid, benzoic?
No, decanedioic—
It helps to make nylons, fantastic!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Saigon fell to the Commies, a pity,
Although many are now sitting pretty.
Since the war's gone away,
Should you visit today
It's officially Ho Chi Minh City.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"We cannot cook for toffee," say teens.
And their phrasing? I know what that means!
They have not learned the skills
That long practice instills.
What they mean is they can't cook for beans.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The blindsided lawyer yelled "Twit!
There's no trusting you, not the least bit.
Why, you seem not to care
If I'm caught unaware —
One more thing, and I swear, I will quit!"

limerick_list.author: nevadaace
limerick_list.text:
My kitty cat mews in frustration
As a develin shrieks with elation.
It flies past my flat
And so riles the cat
That she might have to take medication.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Thanksgiving's the name of this cactus.
The bright flowers are bound to attract us
On this plant from Brazil.
The name crab cactus will
Never faze us—it just won't impact us.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Have some cider—it's apples' surprise,
Made from fruit, under Somerset skies;
Don't abstain like a monk,
But don't drink like a skunk—
Leave a bit of the crop to make pies!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Eradiate's here in my reading,
So a good definition I'm needing.
I see "radiate" will do.
(I am asking: Don't you
Think that English could use a good weeding?)

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
At the florist's, with finances scant,
Add some fern; it's a flowerless plant
That you'll see will pad out
A small bunch, and add clout,
To a birthday bouquet for your aunt.

limerick_list.author: Screenhog
limerick_list.text:
Gold is a metal that gleams,
And is won by Olympian teams.
It makes glittery things
Like five Christmastime rings,
And inhabits a billionaire's dreams.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Take four points (A to D) in a row;
Their cross ratio's easy to know:
It's AC × BD
Per AD × BC.
Turn your quiz in and then you can go.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Evanescent or fleeting?  Good gracious!
Our hostesses?  Never! Flirtatious,
Sagacious, vivacious —
But always tenacious.
Few geishas are ever fugacious.

limerick_list.author: eris8x6
limerick_list.text:
Some Greeks and Egyptians were spoiled
And they wore their hair scented and oiled.
Their unguents of spice
Would be kept in a nice
Alabastron, bejewelled and foiled.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Your book is confusedly written.
It mixes up France with Great Britain,
And Salvador Dali
With Rembrandt, by golly.
I'm miffed! As your agent I'm quittin'!

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Abudefduf is not some mistake
That a kid on a keyboard would make
When he randomly hits
Any key with his mitts;
It's a "damsel fish"—no, it's not fake.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A cultured official named Herman
Sent a firman. We couldn't determine
What he meant till a clerk,
Who by birth was a Turk,
Translated it back into German.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
They were happy; of that there's no doubt,
But they've just had a sad falling-out.
The invective, the blaming!
They're beyond all reclaiming.
Seems he's eaten her last pan-fried trout.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The word driftage—it means "deviation
From your path," which may lead to frustration,
So exert enough force
To get back on your course,
So you'll reach your preferred destination.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Our new logo," cried Hattie, emphatical,
"Needs a symbol, but not one aquatical.
We raise dogs; use a puppy,
You fool, not a guppy.
A canine's much more emblematical."

limerick_list.author: sl8ofhand
limerick_list.text:
Supermodels are taught to act haughtily,
To show off their assets quite bawdily;
And to turn and look back
At the lens-toting pack
To ensure that the camera's aimed caudally.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
Said the madam, "I'm getting too old
For the game: time to quit, so I'm told.
As a bawd I'm just bored
With the whores in my horde.
I deserve to come in from the cold."

limerick_list.author: Mr E S
limerick_list.text:
Said Blanche to a blancher, "I say,
If you keep this food boiling all day,
All the flavor you'll lose,
Not to mention the hues,
And you'll just have to throw it away."

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
England's Amesbury was old when the Dane
Gazed on Stonehenge upon Salisbury Plain.
Its namesake in Mass.
Guards the Merrimack's pass
Before Salisbury meets Gulf of Maine.

limerick_list.author: CruzerX
limerick_list.text:
See that chick in the Jag? What a witch!
There just ain't any bitchier bitch.
And she bitchily knows
That her bitchiness shows,
'Cause she just ran me into a ditch!

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Boasted Sammy the snake, "For first course-o,
I know I could eat a whole horse-o."
"Don't exaggerate, Sam;
That's too much," said his mam.
But not so: it's now horse-shaped, Sam's torso!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In her office, they're docile as lambs.
There's no cursing, no "Hell"s and no "Damn"s,
And as patients depart,
They express, from the heart,
Many "Wow"s and a few "Thank you, ma'am"s.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
His writing's a sickly confection
Of sentiment, styled to 'perfection'.
To this treacly mix
He should add a sour fix,
And make bitter the sweet through correction.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
My computer collection's complete,
Since my Igor did something so sweet:
From the dark and the rain,
He's returned with a brain—
A computer that's made out of meat.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
A monk, a devout Augustinian,
Saw an infant (by chance, Carthaginian)
Grasp a bar, hang suspended.
Monastic life ended—
"Good God! It's the reflex, darwinian!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When Jen's husband went out on a bender,
This event would routinely engender
Both disgust and dismay.
When he got home OK,
She'd surrender—excuse the offender.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Great blue heron: tall wader delightful
(Wingspread almost 6 feet); he's a sightful.
Statuesque near the pier,
Fish, frogs, rodents he'll spear.
So I'm pleased he considers me frightful.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"When I'm wearing my suit and a vest,
I attest that I'm properly drest.
If distressingly pressed,
I'll say dressed," Jess confessed,
But he stressed it was drest he liked best.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
It is true what for long has been rumored:
That my daughter I've finally humored.
She's now wearing loose trousers —
Gets whistles and "Wowsers!"
As she strolls on the strand, fully bloomered.

limerick_list.author: alkahuna
limerick_list.text:
Are you thinking of suing a pastor?
In days past, 'twould have been a disaster,
For all he would need
Was to prove he could read,
And they couldn't dismiss the case faster!

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
My dear Tante Camille Pilkington-Pie,
Although I'm the pomme of her eye,
Will make sure I remember
Her birthday — December
The second, or feathers will fly!

limerick_list.author: Lostock Hall
limerick_list.text:
The bagpipes of Edinburgh skirled.
The clansmen in tartan kilts twirled.
"Scots Wha Ha'e," they were yell'n
To welcome McGellan,
The Jock who first sailed round the world.

limerick_list.author: Jim Vincent
limerick_list.text:
Colonel Vincent was faithful in life.
In the army temptations were rife,
But his colleagues observed
He committedly served
God and country, his children, his wife.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Your pimple! It's far from concealable
(That means hide-able) — but it is heal-able.
If you'll keep your skin clean,
You will see what I mean;
Then your zit won't be such a big deal-able.

limerick_list.author: Shelby Forrest and Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
"Calee-fawn-ee-uh's" governor, Arnie,
Sees his law-making bunch as a carnie.
They're "girly men"—wimps,
He declares, but this simp's
Just a RINO and chock-full of blarney.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
For this test, put the volatile oil
In a cup, close it up, let it boil.
Well, not boil, but just heat
To its flash point—don't cheat!
(That's according to Abel, not Hoyle.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What's a death march? Three meanings, say I:
 People herded in groups—many die—
Or a pace slowly made
In a Christmas parade,
Or a bike ride that may go awry.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What are cervices?  Lexical checks
Say: the plural of cervix, or "necks";
But I'm somewhat confused,
As the word's mostly used
For the womb of the feminine sex.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
At the seashore, Louisa Sue Sutton
Demurely unbuttoned a button,
Then dipped her big toe in,
And Whoa! she kept goin'
Abashlessly straight down to nuttin'.

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
If you're quarrelsome, aggressive or rude,
And you're ready to fight with some dude,
You've a chip on your shoulder—
You're angry and colder:
We can tell that you're in a bad mood.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
My dad raises funds for the Rotary,
Along with a circle, or coterie,
Of like-minded fellows
Who drive things with bellows
And pistons and gearings all motor-y.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
Now don't blame your sweat, it's not fair;
It's bacteria stinking up there.
Undergo electrolysis:
Bacteriolysis!
There! Doesn't that clear the hair!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Malaria isn't esthetic.
Though for days you may be apyretic,
Chills and fevers return
And your head starts to burn,
And you tremble and call for a medic.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Old Fred, the frail homeowner, mutters,
"Every year I must clean these damn gutters.
Tree debris: needles, leaves
Rot and clog up the eaves.
I hate ladders," as downward he flutters.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
The old homestead, abandoned, unsold,
Needs a jolly good clean, he's been told.
He unlatches the shutters,
And sneezes and splutters,
From thick clouds of dust, and the mould.

limerick_list.author: BobRichmond
limerick_list.text:
My wife's bootyliciousness rises;
Her magnificent butt has won prizes.
But now I'm appalled
To learn I've been called
To pay up by the court of assizes.

limerick_list.author: Carlos M
limerick_list.text:
The bandoneon, a big concertina,
Is played all across Argentina.
And I give you my word,
For its sound to be heard
Just go stand on a corner (esquina).

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The adder's a kind of a viper,
A terrestrial, venomous sniper.
But an adder can be
One who tots up your fee,
So with either you might pay the piper.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
From Saskatchewan, fed by the snows,
The Assiniboine River now flows
To the east—to the Red,
Which runs northward instead
To Lake Winnipeg. That's how it goes.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Dale Chihuly, fine artist in glass,
Creates works that museums amass.
Fragile forms with finesse,
Vibrant hues that impress—
If I owned some, this joint would have class.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
The wives of the barons one day
Commanded the woodwinds to play.
The whole baronetage
Enjoyed clarinet, edg-
ing out the French horn (très passé).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
At first, I thought: "Wow! A mirage—
See that plane? It has no empennage!"
But without any tail,
The plane crashed in a dale,
And I'm writing this sad reportage.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Crafty Cupid declared himself smart,
Aimed his dart right at Bart's crux of heart,
Where its four chambers meet.
"He'll sing love songs, so sweet!"
But he hit the wrong part, got a fart.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
In a plant, an accessory cell
Can protect and rebuff and repel.
(Though "a phone that you choose
'Cause it goes with your shoes"
Is a good definition as well.)

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Libs flame Donald for what he has written:
By emails and fake news he's bitten.
But I love him extremely
For tweetstorms unseemly;
The meaner he gets, the more smitten.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
He's working for me and for you
In a job that the locals won't do;
He's that guy at the store
Who's employed while-U-snore—
Springfield's Kwik-E-Mart owner, Apu.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Look, why don't you take a bo-peep
At the shed, where the shivering sheep
Have been shorn of their wool—
Maybe three whole bags full—
And are so bloody cold they've lost sleep.

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
In a not-so-cheap book that I bought,
Something happened that just hadn't ought.
A crack in the back,
Freeing pages, alack —
Thermal binding, it isn't so hot.

limerick_list.author: Jean McEwen
limerick_list.text:
For trials of domestic relations
With tensions and crass accusations
Between mothers and dads
O'er their lassies and lads,
Family court's just a mess of frustrations.

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
My area code is comprised
Of three digits (it's handily sized).
With demand at the max
For both cell phone and fax,
The number of codes was revised.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Ebullient she was, not bombastic,
As she cried, "My new nose job's fantastic!
It's not jutting protuberantly,"
She continued, exuberantly.
"Plastic surgery, though, can be drastic."

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Cricetids can't hope to control
What they see when they go for a stroll,
But the view from a wheel
Has a timeless appeal
For a hamster, or gerbil, or vole.

limerick_list.author: cecelia
limerick_list.text:
She felt bad — she'd been formally chided,
For her writing was often derided.
Seemed she had great potential
For "inconsequential",
So her work limped along quite lopsided.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Here's a word that is rare, obsolete.
Without it our list's not complete.
It's a noun; means "decree."
A defeat it would be
If I couldn't find use for decrete.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Here's my ancient photography trunk
That contains cc filters and junk.
When lighting's off kilter
I would screw on a filter.
But with Photoshop, those are worth bunk.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Differentiate distance by time,
And the outcome's a vector that I'm
Now about to reveal
With Newtonian zeal—
It's velocity (metred in rhyme).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The bryony's one kind of vine
That can not be considered benign.
There is nothing poetic
About this emetic;
So don't add its root to my wine.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Every newspaperman in the East
Calls me "Bigfoot," though I'm not that beast.
Each new column I write
Seems insightful and bright
And ensures that my rep is increased.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Artemisia: a plant with a name
That attracts, like a moth to a flame;
But it's toxic, this root?
And called wormwood, to boot?
Now it just doesn't feel quite the same.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Ms Luce, with a glint in her eye,
Murmured "Age before beauty" (Oh, my!)
To Ms Parker in line,
But then "Pearls before swine"
Was the acid-tongued writer's reply.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
One's IQ, on its own, will not do:
There's emotional intelligence too.
Once aware of all feelings,
You may handle your dealings
With others from their point of view.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
When you Gram stain a bunch of bacteria,
You establish these sorting criteria:
See, this violet-stained bunch
Packs Gram-positive punch,
While Gram-negative's pink (not Listeria).

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
When a cow (with a bull) shares a womb,
She's a freemartin, you can assume.
They will swap DNA;
She'll be sterile that way.
And so never to calve is her doom.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
The coconut crab lives on land,
But it usually hides in the sand.
With its pincers it cuts
Through the shells of the nuts
Fallen down from the trees on the strand.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
What is glottochronology?  It
Is the study of languages knit
By a common thread, tracing
The rate of replacing
The vocabs to guess when they split.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Take expede and impede. Words like those
Were once equally used, history shows.
Yet one faded away,
While one's with us today.
But the question is why. No one knows.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
Betsy found a strange man in her bed
Who ignored every word that she said.
Of reactions no trace
When she slapped his straight face:
He just lay there while cutting her dead.

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
The linguist was filled with frustration
While trying to give a narration
For each consonant stop
Got an extra air pop
Which is what he would call affrication.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The tall sailor-man swam near the fort
Having missed the "Beware — Sharks!" report.
As he dove in warm seas,
Something chomped 'neath his knees —
He fought hard, but alas, came up short.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
When a church or a courthouse grows high,
Let a piece of it reach for the sky.
To summon or warn
(As well as adorn),
A bell tower catches your eye.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Stephen Breyer's a judge on a court
That Americans like to support
When we think a decision
Accords with our vision—
Like, say, it's okay to abort.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
An adult ajolote has gills
But still enjoys sexual thrills.
"You are so immature,"
Says his mate, "That's for sure.
Don't go play with your friends, pay some bills!"

limerick_list.author: Peter Meyer
limerick_list.text:
Educationists mostly are teachers
Possessed of some really swell features.
Some even teach grammar
With outspoken glamour,
Though some are unsavoury creatures.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Life comes easy to me since I'm blonde
In that shade of which all men are fond.
I've got looks, I've got class,
And a dynamite ass,
And an honest-to-God magic wand.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
My great-grandad, the back washer, said,
"Way back when, all the work was co-ed,
But the job title's bull!
All we washed was the wool.
From day one, I was greatly misled."

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
A pernicious event, sad to see,
Was reversed by infusions of tea:
The explorers were doomed
Till they boiled and consumed
Arborvitae, a curative tree.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Does a mayfly, who lives but one day,
Find life sweet in ephemeral play?
A bare dot on life's page,
It won't plan for old age
In its blink-and-you-miss-it-all stay.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
Antisegregation means rights,
So that blacks attend classes with whites.
Brown v. Board's now effected.
The Supreme Court rejected
Those old Plessy v. Ferguson cites.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
My abstinent girlfriend, Enola,
Loves whiskey and Price Chopper cola.
We drink until one
And have riotous fun
Watching reruns of Charlie and Lola.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
My Dad doesn't like what's on top a'
Our outhouse: a roof of new copper.
He said, "But I do go
For roofs of aerugo;
If Mum tries to clean it, you stop 'er."

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Queen Elizabeth, that is, the First,
Was in matters of state deeply versed.
She promoted fair laws
And the Protestant cause,
Which, by some Catholic people, was cursed.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When parties bilaterally agree,
Issue jointly a friendly decree,
And together they act—
Sign a treaty or pact—
There are two sides, in fact, and not three.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
This fine morning we're all on the hunt
For a breakfast of plain cluck and grunt.
This farm family begs
For just bacon and eggs.
Nothing fancy — we're hicks, to be blunt.

limerick_list.author: turnip
Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
The fairy-wren sings at its nest,
"Little eggs, you're the sweetest and best."
Once they hatch, chicks repeat,
"Eggs are best!" "Sweet, sweet, sweet."
The best mimic's fed more than the rest.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
First she served me a plate of spaghetti,
Then a freshly baked apple brown Betty.
To the meal, my reaction
Was utmost attraction—
Erotic as D. G. Rossetti.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's a car expert Edgar consults
Who says, "Front seats are just for adults.
Kids cause crashes!" "Yet, sir,
If the accidents occur
In the back seat, the kids are results."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
These old legs need some space to feel free,
So it's seats behind bulkheads for me.
An airplane partition
Is no imposition…
Unlike headrests assaulting each knee.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The blow to Joe's gut was traumatic
To his liver; its function's erratic.
It seems to be leaking,
And technically speaking
The fluid is extrahepatic.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Attracted to (feeling akin)
Or entering via the skin,
Such a virus would be
Dermotropic — a flea
Could convey one, or even a pin.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
Here are barfulous things in a list:
First, a pus-filled sebaceous-type cyst,
Summer roadkill's putrescence,
A diaper's rank essence—
These all make me retch! Get the gist?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A barfly—belligerent, barmy—
Was threatening bodily harm. He
Was told by a chap,
"I'd be shutting your trap,"
And retorted with, "You and what army?"

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
What I learned knocked me into next week!
It was dumbfounding. See? I can't speak.
My bewilderment's such
That my stomach I clutch:
My old man is a werewolf, the freak!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
I would bet on our getting bogged down
In that bog that's a slog out of town.
With our luck, we'll get stuck,
In the mire and the muck,
And (it boggles the mind) we could drown.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When he died (due to bowel congestion?),
Alexander's great buddy, Hephaestion,
Was honored with games
Of which one of the aims
Was to make his name famous—no question!

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
To read it is taking me ages,
This contract of eighty-two pages.
I'll just sign it and hope
I can cover the scope
It requires, and so earn my wages.

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
He calls himself "Japanese Rocky",
And claims his hometown's Nagasaki.
But whenever he'll box
He'll absorb lots of shocks,
For his head is enormous and blocky.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
Join the shanks of some hooks, two or three:
That's a gang hook, we say here at sea.
You like fishing? Add bait.
You want pieces of eight?
Swing it pirate-wise, mate, just like me!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Counterphobic procedures appear,
On the surface, a little bit queer.
You're confronting the things
That you dread, yet it brings
You the power to conquer your fear.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I didn't feel right in the head,
So I took to a hospital bed
Where I slept over days
In a sedative haze;
With this dauerschlaf, demons got shed.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The highwaymen couch by the road
In the bushes and signal by code.
There's a horse-driven coach
That is on its approach,
So get ready for guns to explode.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Though the prisoner's name is McGee,
He is 5317 to me.
My job is to guard him.
Society's barred him
From living unfettered and free.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
Consider the cute eohippus;
At a gallop it couldn't outstrip us.
The earliest horse,
So we're told, but of course,
Had it lived it might nip us or trip us.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
She will let you write page after page
On her life on the screen and the stage.
But one thing you must guess,
For she'll never confess
To her true chronological age.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My doctor has made a selection
For an antibiotic injection.
Extrapulmonary (not
In my lung)—there I've got
What's called pleurisy—pleural infection.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
Will this airplane fall out of the sky?
If a DVT strikes, will I die?
Actuarial questions—
Or autosuggestions?
No matter: too risky to fly!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
King Gustav III had a fear:
"Drinking coffee's a hazard, it's clear!
I will prove it," said he.
"Convict A? You'll drink tea.
Convict B? Coffee, year after year."

limerick_list.author: Margaret Ford
limerick_list.text:
Yeah, you'll rock when you play on his daxophone
(Though your glockenspiel's fine, this gem packs a tone).
You'll get Bach from a tongue
(On a block) which is sprung.
Please don't knock it—he'll bring out his saxophone.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
Our chamber of commerce promotes
This fair city with great, pithy quotes:
"Come to Jackrabbit Flats,
Now with far fewer rats"
And "Our town—think Sheboygan with goats."

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
Take some oranges, cloves and port wine;
Mix and heat till the flavours combine.
Can you still pronounce "triple
Episcopal tipple"
When you've drunk of this liquor divine?

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
If you're feeling all weak and aweary,
In other words generally dreary,
Have a nice cup of tea,
And I'm sure you'll agree,
It will make you feel so much more cheery.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Call it COR-deel or call it Cor-DEEL—
Whichever has greater appeal.
There are ten thousand souls
On municipal rolls
In this town down in Georgia—for real!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The bull gave a heart-rending cry
Since, befuddled, he couldn't see why,
So malignly inclined,
We've been trying to blind,
Taking aim at some hapless bull's eye.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My blind date? She was mute as a dummy,
And as stiff as a tightly wound mummy.
Expecting exanimateness,
I was shocked by the animateness
I found once we two became chummy.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If you visit your doctor and hear
That your cornea isn't quite clear,
In your visual field
The albugo revealed
May cause shadows that don't disappear.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
What is bawdy is changing anew.
Baring ankle was once derring-do.
Once a bust, proudly thrust,
Was incitement to lust.
Now it's mostly for casual view.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
I was tipping the trash, then a shout—
"William, don't throw the dear baby out
With the bathwater, please!"
(I was chucking fresh peas
With old eggshells—daft action no doubt!)

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
A commander is judged by his war,
And his war is assessed by the score.
A prudent retreat
Is a shameful defeat.
When losing, commanders war more.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Some claim gnosis, so sure that they know.
Au contraire, I've agnosis; and so
I will sit on the fence,
Truly lacking a sense
As to which side I'll throw my chapeau.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Maude's sister complains Maude is bossy,
While Laura, in Maude's eyes, seems dossy.
"Maude, you live like a monk!"
"Laura, you fall for junk—
Yes, your junk food and jewelry—all drossy!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Free admission will go to the guy
Who posts ads on his property. Why?
Every bill pass, we know,
Means more folks at the show
Who will like what they see buy and buy.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Do you know why this term is attractive?
Presupposing a truth makes it factive.
You've discovered this word
With that knowledge conferred.
Here, discovered and why are proactive.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Dietrich Bonhöffer, protestant pastor,
Preached out against Nazi disaster.
He died as a martyr,
Both purer and smarter.
"Mein Führer? No! Vater's my master."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I addressed the entire congregation.
I was focused and spoke of creation,
Then I seemed quite insane—
Said that Abel killed Cain—
I'm confused when I lose concentration.

limerick_list.author: Bob Egg
limerick_list.text:
I'm a gentleman, suave, well-to-do;
On my promises I'll follow through.
So don't think it absurd
When I keep to my word
And pen verse about pee-pee and poo.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
While a courtier, favoured at court,
Was enlightened and wise and was thought
To be cultured, aesthetic,
Refined and poetic,
The whims of a king he'd not thwart.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"All the rest of you plants are disasters,"
The dwarf dandelions said. "We're the masters.
We're high class, upper crust.
You'll  admit it, we trust,
As our family members are asters."

limerick_list.author: Aliza
limerick_list.text:
I went to the doc with abdominal
Aorta occlusion — not nominal.
The big artery's hard,
So she'll scrape out the lard
With her surgical skills quite phenomenal!

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
When the British say "glasshouse", they mean
A glass house in which plants can be seen.
Here both flowers and fruit,
Well protected, take root.
Some say "greenhouse" — its contents are green.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
The witch Edna Garlick forspoke
Frogs and toads in her cottage to smoke:
"I forbid you to puff!
If you need that vile stuff,
Jump and smoke in your lake till you croak."

limerick_list.author: Sybil Society
limerick_list.text:
Brenda blotted her tears on her blouse
While bemoaning the beaux of her spouse—
"He's been carrying on
With Marie, Dick, and John;
My boudoir has become a full house!"

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
In an effort to stop being bored,
Since the firing fiasco with Ford,
Susan's learned how to code
And her programming's flowed
To create an A.I. code-named "Sword".

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"Roasted witch, poisoned food, butchered toes —
Grimm's too grim for young minds; out it goes!"
Until Bettelheim said
That it's good for the head:
Both enchanted and chilled, a child grows.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I will free Rosemarie—disenthrall
Her from zealotry, once and for all!
As she's under the spell
Of a guru from hell,
I may well be involved in a brawl.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Our art teacher figured, supposingly,
That our model was feckless. She'd dozingly
Dropped her jaw in a snore.
"You don't work here no more.
There's the door!" roared our tutor disposingly.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
This asthenia's making me mild
(I am weak, with the strength of a child).
Now let's guess at the reasons:
I've too many seasons?
Or maybe my lover just smiled!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Every day I consume some red wine,
Having heard it would keep my health fine.
I drink every last glass
In the hope, as years pass,
That the obits I read won't be mine.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My poor henhouse, perched under the trees,
Is the scene for a dreadful disease
Called fowl pest or fowl plague.
Its dire symptoms, not vague,
Are destroying my stock by degrees.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
'Twas the day that Her Majesty chose
To go visit her empire's chateaus.
At each stop, the men blinked
And the servant boys winked...
For the emperess wore her new clothes.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
What's a censor?  A critic who's sought
To evaluate films you'd have bought,
If not banned by a man
Who's scanned more than you can,
And then feels he's seen more than you ought.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
10, 9, 8... "Don't you dare say you've got"
7, 6... "the 'flu. Scott, if you're not"
5, 4, 3... "out of bed,"
2, 1, Blast Off! "YOU'RE DEAD!"
(Mother's giving a rocket to Scott.)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Our son bought a beat-up jalopy;
It's rusted and busted and sloppy.
Though it isn't quite drivable,
He hopes it's revivable
With money from Mommy and Poppy.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
"Words ending in buck," said my son,
"Are all antelopes—bushbuck is one.
Also waterbuck, reedbuck,
Whatever-you-need-buck,
And springbuck…" (He'd only begun.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A shrimp plies a whale with libation,
Then they wed in complete adoration.
Cumacea are shrewd:
Get a blubber-boy stewed
And he'll marry beneath his cetacean.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
Be quiet, child, don't say a word.
Look there, where the nettle's all furred.
If you look, you may see,
There's a red barnabee
With black spots. That's a true ladybird.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
"The best Hitchcock that he never made":
Archie Leach and Kath Ruston there played
A couple that itches
To find the lost riches
That a dead man's last message displayed.

limerick_list.author: Rose
limerick_list.text:
If a science degree was your aim,
These letters now follow your name.
(Get them simply by skimming
The uni: Bronze Swimming
Certificate sounds just the same!)

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
When I go on safari, I find
Cargo pockets the very best kind.
Nothing else can compete
With the flap and the pleat—
So your goodies are not left behind.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Post-war capital, Bonn by the Rhine,
Was, for Adenauer, simply divine:
Not too far from Cologne
Where he'd been so well known,
And a good place to wine and to dine.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"This coke is incredibly strong,
And I'll sell you a pound for a song."
But I just turned away.
I could hear Momma say,
"Son, illegal drug chaffery's wrong!"

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
His mates all appeared bright and breezy
As they took the exam; Quinn felt queasy,
But then really flew through it.
"So simple! I knew it!"
He bragged. "It was just easy-peasy."

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Other spiders suck bugs and such dry.
Not the panther-named kiplingi. Why
Does a herbivore need
To leap for its feed?
To evade stinging ants, I reply.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Doctors ordered a test; you are tense.
The reagent is testing for Bence-
Jones, a protein one sees
In a dreaded disease,
So you feel you may die of suspense.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If your home is infested, you need
A good disinfestation, agreed?
If it's flies, you should spray.
If it's mice, I would say
Purchase 200 cats with all speed.

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
The attractive incentive I've planned
Is a bonus scheme worth half a grand.
That's the carrot. The stick
Is my foreman—meet Mick.
If he catches you slacking you're canned.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Does my girlfriend love ferrets? And how!
She perceives them to be her cash cow.
In groups, they sell well.
She's a hit, I can tell,
In the busyness business right now.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
My manuscript — flat-out rejected! —
Was also so damned disrespected.
Disjection's the worst
(Getting scattered, dispersed).
It went flying — can't be resurrected.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I go out with a cougar named Gert.
She's well-off, whereas I'm poor as dirt.
She will pay me with meals
And with gifts.  When she feels
In the mood, I pay her with dessert.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
You did not get a shot? What a sin!
The measles are doing you in;
I can see that you gotta
Whole ungodly lotta
Eruptions all over your skin.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Down the streets of the 'hood he will tread,
A cuculla pulled over his head.
What mystery face,
What sex, age or race?
It's a 'hoodie' inspiring some dread.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
At age eighty, my sins I repented;
I lamented and then felt contented.
Since that day I've forgotten
Those deeds that were rotten,
But I'm saved (though I'm somewhat demented).

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
This bridle is well worth the wait.
Note the crownpiece they chose to create:
Where it lies on the head,
They have woven in thread
Of pure silver—my horse will look great.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Do our rulers have ethical health?
No, they're mostly old geezers with wealth.
Was chrysocracy bred
In democracy's bed?
Were we sleeping? Or did they use stealth?

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Every morning, I drive to the store
And hit potholes and frost heaves galore.
Nasty craters and hills
Lead to car repair bills
And a backbone that's chronically sore.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
Destabilized elements may
Sustain radioactive decay,
Where the nuclei purge,
And new atoms emerge:
Daughter nuclides that join in the fray.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Our foes sent a cartload of spies
Who dispersed in civilian disguise.
Invading headquarters,
They mixed up our orders—
We received twenty cartloads of ties.

limerick_list.author: GeneralE
limerick_list.text:
A bay is a horse of that hue,
And some people call laurels that, too;
It's a hound's hunting call,
Or a window (three-wall)—
San Francisco's? A waterfront view.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
You should never engage with a bickerer —
A petulant, petty fight-pickerer.
He'll quarrel and brawl,
And profess to know all,
When his skull couldn't be any thickerer.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
Every cube has six faces, it's true.
This one's painted in red, green and blue,
And in white and in black;
If you look at the back
There's a Valentine's heart just for you.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
You want me to strike off your fetter?
I can write your attorney a letter,
But for now, I'm afraid,
Though I'll offer you aid,
Of escape I can't be an abettor.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Ten press-ups, then run on the spot.
Now some weights (if it isn't too hot).
Head outdoors (if not raining),
Complete circuit training:
Three beers, and say "Cheers!" — down the lot!

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
What could happen, or fall through the gaps,
Is conditional — prone to collapse.
Life is iffy, capricious.
I have doubts; is that specious?
It's a definite maybe. Perhaps.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
Said a tall, duncish  player, "My forte
Is to dunk in my favorite sport,
But my team gets upset
When I slam through the net
At the other team's end of the court."

limerick_list.author: Nitelaf
limerick_list.text:
Though infrequently written or heard,
Its usage is not that absurd,
So there's no need to edit.
Miss Hoover has said it:
"A perfectly cromulent word!"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Coediting isn't much fun
When your peers number fifty-and-one.
Some redactors are strict,
Picking nits, and get ticked
Seeing "stet" next to edits they've done.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Dull and dreary, the shadowy light
Helps disguise what she turns from in fright;
Her reflection adds gloom
To the darkening room.
Soon her scars will be hidden by night.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Engaged in a causerie, Matt
And Melinda discussed this and that.
Nothing deep or profound,
Just who's sleeping around,
Or why stripes make Melinda look fat.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
If someone's exceedingly driven,
This is axiomatically given:
He should certainly stop,
Else the curtain may drop.
What's the point, if a life's not worth livin'?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If you want a career that's ascendant,
So you'll never be broke or dependent,
Education's the key —
Then you won't have to be
Either car-hop or washroom attendant.

limerick_list.author: Cuttlefish
limerick_list.text:
The union rep started to grin:
"You may find that the odds are too thin
On your own. Here's the 'but':
There's no limit to what
We can do if we all just chip in."

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
My son gave me cause to have dread;
From Jew he'd turned Christian.  I fled
To my temple — told Yahweh.
A voice came from fa' way:
"It's funny you say that," it said.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Ecclesia Penitens: Oops!
I'd say yours is the largest of groups.
Renounce sins as you dwell
Between heaven and hell.
Make amends—you'll be jumping through hoops.

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Abandonment's not very nice.
'Fore you do it, you'd better think twice:
It's awfully unkind
To leave children behind,
And illegal, so take my advice.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The cosmist John Fiske once opined
On the way that the world is designed:
Not just theism's true—
Evolution is, too,
And its highest achievement? The mind.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Tired of coddling toddlers all day?
Then treat teens. They're an ailment buffet.
Adolescent theatrics
Add spice. Ephebiatrics
Tracks puberty's quirks underway.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle and mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
The colorless cetane is found
In petroleum, deep in the ground.
From its rating one learns
How a diesel fuel burns
In compression and pistons rebound.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Dribs and drabs: we just can't let you pay
Off your debt in this haphazard way.
Give us dollars, not dimes.
Though we know it's hard times
Your arrearage still causes dismay .

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"What on earth," Mary asked, "can compare
To a graceful and spare flying mare?"
"What? A horse that can soar?"
"No, in wrestling, you floor
Your opponent, flipped up in the air."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
It's fakelore, the stuff in these tales—
Pecos Bill and his storied travails—
Just a clever invention
In its every dimension,
But effective. Check out the book's sales.

limerick_list.author: Snowy Owl and Znirk
limerick_list.text:
When alien monsters break free
And attack in a brain-eating spree,
Don't jump up in alarm, lest
You jostle your armrest
And topple your drink on my knee.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
This project to some seems absurd.
It's outrageous, or so I have heard.
It's bizarre, I agree,
But what is plain to me
Is insane is the apposite word.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
When you served vegetarian turkey,
Our aliment quickly turned quirky.
How much time should it take
For your oven to bake
Sixteen pounds of a free-range tofurkey?

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai and mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
All the Plantae show strange alternation
In the ploidy of each generation.
When gametophytes mate,
These young haploids create
A new diploid, a fresh variation.

limerick_list.author: Snowy Owl
limerick_list.text:
An appendage that's shaped like a wing,
That's the long and the short of the thing.
There are alae on flies,
Maple seeds in the skies,
And my nostrils, now pierced by a ring.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
A great galleon, yet light on his feet,
The old burgher sailed in off the street.
For his aldermanly girth,
Patrons left a broad berth,
Where he anchored his favorite seat.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Dodgy Dan just delivered the swag,
But — not wanting remotely to flag
His behaviour (look funny!) —
The counterfeit money
He'd wrapped in a brown paper bag.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
There's a bench dog aligned with my vise,
So all woodworking's true and precise.
I do scrollwork and molding;
Vise and dog do the holding.
Simple pegs may be worth twice their price.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Let us arm every student and teacher.
Give a gun to each pastor and preacher.
And let us not trifle
With handgun or rifle.
Ensure that they sport every feature.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
An optometrist frowned at the piles—
Patient records ascending for miles.
So he said, "I wish these
Were all saved on PCs."
His mission: computerize files.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
My back, out of whack in the spine,
Chiropractors once tried to align.
They kneaded and pushed,
I groaned and they shushed
'Til at last I yelled, "Stop! You're malign!"

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Don't like facets? Then leave them alone;
Grind some cabs (most are domed) from your stone.
When stone's slabbed and cabbed well,
Buyers hurry, pell-mell,
And you fast become very well-known.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
This microscope specimen's not
Clearly showing the structure it's got,
So a counterstain, blue,
Should provide us a view
Of the features we're hoping to spot.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Some ex-students decided to sue
Sketchy real estate college, Trump U.
"The Donald" flashed mettle—
"I never will settle!"
Now twenty-five million is due.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A fellow who trotted the globe
Now sits in his house in a robe.
He fears open spaces
And dreads public places.
We call him an agoraphobe.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My thinking melts back into magma
When I look at that graceful stalagma.
I am awed, still as death,
And I'm holding my breath,
With a spellbound, inert diaphragma.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Rosalinda is gorgeous in pink!
Becky's body could drive me to drink.
Co-ed classes are great—
Did you hear about Kate?
Then there's Shakespeare, a writer, I think.

limerick_list.author: Quickbeam
limerick_list.text:
If Athenians leave you ecstatic,
Or you favour words curt yet dramatic,
Atticism's your creed,
But please don't think you need
To start spending more time in the attic.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I'm a 'here and there' kind of a guy
(Going hither and thither). That's why
I prefer going out,
Unconfined—get about.
Yes, a 'to and fro' fellow am I.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
"My podiatry test? Yes, I cheated.
Don't fire me, please," I entreated.
Since they did, heaven knows,
I can not check your toes.
With my clinic now closed, I'm defeated.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
His home brew's the last of the batch
He's been saving for Saturday's match.
With his pals he will sup,
And they'll shout for the cup
Between, "Cheers, mate! Chin chin! Down the hatch!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Such a jerk, you defame Doctor Salk on
Those dumb radio programs you talk on.
You're a creep, a baboon,
A moronic buffoon!
I disworship the ground that you walk on.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
When detectives are solving their cases,
A dactylogram's often the basis.
They'll get valuable hints
By developing prints
From a criminal's fingerprint traces.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
Catherine the Great was first wed,
To a man who would not share her bed.
So one clearly can see
Why Peter the Three
Was disposed of.  He wound up quite dead!

limerick_list.author: Bob Colonna
limerick_list.text:
Old sailormen chronicle still
The adventures of Barnacle Bill.
Since his manners were crude,
All the stories are lewd
And they pack a hedonical thrill.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Our recruits here are all warmly greeted,
Then screenings are fairly completed.
Once positions are filled,
All the rest will be killed.
Until then, you'll be equitably treated.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
If the ducks in your pond make you ill,
You will doubtless need many a pill
That's prescribed by some quack
At ten dollars a crack,
And then you'll have to (web)foot the bill.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
Tests of reading kept black folks away
From the polls, but to white folks' dismay,
The tests also stripped rights
From illiterate whites.
But the grandfather clause saved the day.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
I won't dress up in any old rag,
I wear heels, and I carry a bag—
But you see, I'm a guy,
So you might say that I
Have a high coefficient of drag.

limerick_list.author: Bit
limerick_list.text:
He feasts while we're starving through droughts.
Of his leadership skills, there are doubts.
He's a governing guy
Called a dictator.  Why?
'Cause he dictates the laws that he flouts.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
He has thousands of hours in his book
On De Havilland Beavers; just look
At his eyes and you'll see
He's a bush pilot—free,
Since amphibious pathways he took.

limerick_list.author: LMAK
limerick_list.text:
Marine mammals became my obsession.
I quantify every impression.
I record the details
Of dolphins and whales.
Cetologist: that's my profession.

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
George Gordon, Lord Byron, once wrote
At great length on Don Juan, and I quote:
"A hero ...[a] true one...
Our [old] friend Don Juan ..."
Will serve my own rhymes to promote.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I've perfected our race plan. I think
That our crew will be rowing in sync.
We'll be victors with ease.
Don't desynchronize, please!
Hope will sink if we're off by a wink!

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Older children, engrossed in their play,
Hadn't noticed the pup run away.
Now we'd better fan out:
Search all points round about
While we still have some good light of day.

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
Did Egeria, long ago dead
Back in Rome, share the emperor's bed?
Maybe yes, maybe no.
But he valued her so
That he listened to all the nymph said.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
This Victorian bowl made of glass
Has a silvery base adding class.
It's a basket the bride
Is displaying with pride
(While the bridegroom is grabbing her ass).

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
I've found my old boomerang. Wow!
I shall throw it again now — but how?
As my memory's rotten,
I might have forgotten...
Ah, it's coming right back to me now!

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
So you didn't consult, not at all?
"I'm PM, so that's that. Captain's call.
With this sword I thee dub —
Rise, Sir Phil." There's the rub:
On thy sword, mate, thou shortly wilt fall.

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
My power tool smoothes what is rough.
It's a disk sander, sturdy and tough.
It beats working by hand.
The disk rotates to sand,
Grind, abrade, polish, burnish, or buff.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"I don't mean to be vulgar or crass,
But I'm proud of my statue's fine ass.
Made of bright, yellow metal,
This dame's in fine fettle,"
Said the brazier, a worker in brass.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
E: means "energy" in an equation.
EV: car that gets charged at a station.
Eve: first woman from God.
Even: number, not odd.
Event: gala or large celebration.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Order things in a set so, when done,
They will all correspond, one to one,
With the numbers we use
When we count. What ensues?
Countability! Math is such fun!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Define dripple? I'm told "weak or rare."
Though it looks like a verb, please take care:
It's an adjective, but
An enigma, somewhat.
Of its use I remain unaware.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
In photography now you can see
Only digicams, making you free
From the film that would store
All your pictures before.
What gets photo(n)s to chips? CCD.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
"Please encrisp your hair," ordered the earl.
"I detest straightened hair on a girl.
You shall never cavort
Nor set foot in my court
With your tresses possessing no curl."

limerick_list.author: pkwooster
limerick_list.text:
"One more buck-off for Pete!" they all cried,
As I felt my posterior slide
From the back of the horse
With momentum and force.
That dang rodeo wore out my hide!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Discapacitate Lou, if you please,"
Said the boss. I love errands like these!
So I smashed Louie's nose,
Sawed off four of his toes,
Broke three fingers and one of his knees.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Astronauts, please all take note:
The things into space that you tote,
Which stay safe and sound
Way down here on the ground,
In agravic environments, float.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
Stay sane — here's a football boot tip:
Check the studs in the soles and don't slip.
Playing soccer on grass
Is a pain in the ass
If you find that you're losing your grip.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
After fishing the mighty Pacific,
Where gargantuan fish are prolific,
Take your blue marlin prize;
Have it stuffed. Its great size
Is impressive—a trophy terrific.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Though the smoke I inhale's hardly clean,
My new filter tips possibly mean
Lower risk, insofar
As a little less tar
Is breathed in — so I might make eighteen!

limerick_list.author: VERaLOE
limerick_list.text:
Last night I was blowing my nose,
And a blood vessel burst like a hose.
Blood ensanguined my skirt.
Though it did look like dirt,
The dark stain had the shape of a rose.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
I am Susan, called after my mum.
Are there problems? I'd have to say, some.
Once our dentist, the swine,
Mixing her file with mine
Tried to pull her false teeth from my gum.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Since their strategy countered the moves
That we made last we played, it behooves
Us to forge, if we can,
An unbeatable plan—
One the coach likes so much he approves.

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
There's a finch called a crossbill whose beak
Is so twisted it's able to tweak
Or to tweeze pinecone seeds.
Its appearance misleads:
Even Darwin misjudged it a freak.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
As the papal abbreviator, I
Shall draw up the pope's briefs. You ask why
Papal undies require
Such care. Not attire
But papers I'll shortly supply.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
"Get the navy and air force alarmed;
Army too, since our border was harmed!"
"Sir, from air, water, land
None can give us a hand.
They've no fingers, no palms — they're just armed."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Are you hungry? Well, I'm in the mood
For some hot cafeteria food.
Since the place is self-service,
Try not to get nervous,
'Cause dropping your tray would be rude.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Whatever I do or I say,
I'm diabolized every which way.
Those who demonize me
Must be devils. You see,
That ol' turnabout's only fair play.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Drunkard John wastes his days—what a shame—
And his lassitude's mostly to blame:
"A new life I'll begin,
When my ship has come in—
So just wait—soon I'll run this whole game."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Lots of names—this plant's hard to believe.
"Lords and ladies," and "Adam and Eve,"
It's called "cuckoo-pint" too,
"Naked boys"—quite a few—
And it's got a lot more up its sleeve.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Biologism has its attractions.
It examines society's actions
(Both our women's and men's)
Through biology's lens;
It explores our accords and infractions.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
We use bedrock, a good solid noun,
For that layer of earth not far down
That is stable enough
To support homes and stuff.
(Yes, it's also Fred Flintstone's hometown.)

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
It's not Wendy's in little kids' eyes,
Nor McDonald's, though that may surprise.
At times they want treats
Of flame-broiled eats
And repeats of BK Chicken Fries.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
Something basilar lies at the base
Of a skull, or a structure, or vase.
Like the canes of a rose,
Or your toes, I suppose,
Or the great Sherlock Holmes on the case.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
That catgut might rightly belong
Where you're needing a string to be strong.
When you put your request in
For twisted intestine,
Your suturing never goes wrong.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
A fraction of incoming light
Called albedo (from Latin for "white"),
Not absorbed but reflected,
Leaves Earth unaffected
Yet makes it look terrably bright.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Not so bottomless as they may seem,
Deep blue holes are a spring seeker's dream:
Preternaturally pure,
Who's to say what they'll cure,
Or what sins a good soak might redeem?

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
Sam the Swagger's a crime figure — bad,
Well-known felon, so mean he seems mad.
Like a boy playing pranks,
He goes round robbing banks
To impress me (and I'm the lad's dad).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It is cylinder-like in its shape,
And it's smooth so its sides will not scrape.
Not intending to pain us,
It fits in the anus—
From a bougie there's just no escape.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Between me and your loud GOP,
There's much daylight.  We'll never agree!
Whereas Dems have a heart,
Are progressive and smart
And hate guns — hey, don't point that at m

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
The arrière-garde is my soi-disant clique.
Nothing trendy's for me—nothing chic.
Social media? Why?
I'm a démodé guy
Who buys clothes at the Bygones Boutique.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Adfenestration's a burglar's technique:
Through your window he'll quietly sneak.
If you're not at home now
There's a chance, I avow,
You are being ripped off as we speak.

limerick_list.author: psheil and Anna Pestic
limerick_list.text:
From amaze comes a shock (not of hair),
But from hair comes a lock (brown or fair).
Now this lock needs a key;
Music scales next we see.
We amuse with this maze. Oh what flair!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Being shaped like a crow ain't enough
For the corviform raven and chough.
They're refusing to play
With the magpie and jay
Just to show to the crow that they're tough.

limerick_list.author: SusanL and oneslowtyper
limerick_list.text:
The nuns never let him write left,
Though his backhand delivery was deft.
He's bereft of what's right.
Still, the nuns seem uptight
'Cause his writing slants left—and with heft!

limerick_list.author: PGS and waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
Some poetry, once in a while,
Employs Archilochian style.
Iambic satirics —
Invention in lyrics —
It's written with gusto and guile.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
A syringe with detachable spout —
Put it in and then shpritz; take it out.
You can call it a douche bag —
It's not for your bouche (gag) —
A vaginal shower, no doubt.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
The Columbia Icefield may slide
Down the great continental divide,
But meltwater goes forth
To the west, east, and north,
And Canadians view it with pride.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"God's forgiveness is nearly consumed.
All are sinners," our minister fumed.
"But we few know the way
To survive the dark day.
Present parties excepted, we're doomed."

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Caput mortuum (English: "dead head")
Is the alchemists' name (naught to dread!)
For the dregs that remain
From their trying, in vain,
To gain (how insane!) gold from lead.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The highway that takes us from hence
Runs a ways alongside of my fence.
Then the road that we're on
Curves from hither to yon,
And forgetfulness takes us from thence.

limerick_list.author: Brent Annable
limerick_list.text:
My clothesline collapsed with a sloshing,
But with copious squishing and squashing,
I've strung up a line
In this hovel of mine —
Now my bedroom's astring with the washing.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
The achenial sunflower seed
Is a wonderful product, indeed.
What we think is the shell
Is a fruit just as well,
But it's dry and it's thin-walled, agreed?

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
My mare that was pregnant has foaled,
But my daughter is not to be told.
The reason, of course, is
All my baby horses
Are labelled as "beef" and then sold.

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
Why does tax filing time cause such stress?
Wretched forms to fill out—it's a mess!
All confused, you say, "Heck!"
Then you write out a check
For what's due or, at least, your best guess.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
They say, "Girl, you were born of good stock."
But I know that they're trying to mock
The fact that my bones
Are as dense as the stones
In the fences surrounding our flock.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Someone asked, "What the heck's a big rig?"
It's my tractor cum trailer, a big
Cargo-transporting deal,
With a quick-hitch fifth wheel.
How I itch for my next long-haul gig!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
An American diet is key with me.
When cooking you can't be too free with me.
No Thai or Chinese
And no Mexican, please.
All these foods simply do not agree with me.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
"Discernment" this meaning is nudging,
"The faculty (power) for judging",
There's "discrimination" too
For this word far from new:
All old meanings of doom, not for budging.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
The mission this Christmas was handing
Out food to the poor of Pitts Landing.
The fish was, well, odd:
Here's a small piece of cod
That passeth all, all understanding.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I saw Len, was astonished, and then
Did a double take—looking again.
"Len, you've lost lots of weight."
I exclaimed, "You look great.
Give me ten!" Len appended: "Amen!"

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Have we reached the true height of pomposity
To declare that there's no animosity
Between black and white,
Betwixt left and right?
Is no amity here?  No, ferocity.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Let's get into the weeds of this deal:
More specifics should make it more real.
Clever clauses designed
To make truths hard to find
Are deceptive; they're there to conceal.

limerick_list.author: Snowy Owl
limerick_list.text:
My skin isn't apt to seduce,
With these blisters that ooze and peel loose.
I've tried all sorts of gunge,
From green mud to axunge—
Still, I'd rather be me than the goose.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
There's little of night left before us —
Time for one sentimental old chorus
And a parting cup quaffed
At the door — a deep draught,
But we call it a wee doch-an-dorris.

limerick_list.author: Jim Vincent
limerick_list.text:
"The Messiah turned water to wine,
And the taste is supremely divine."
"Hey, well now that He's here,
Could a guy get a beer?"
"Son, you're missing the point of His sign."

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
My poor baby can't sleep. It's so trying
(And tiring). I've tried controlled crying:
Put her down, close the door;
Let her scream, each time more.
Gee, that's tough. Now it's my eyes need drying.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
These paintings of nudes, understand,
Are not porn and they shouldn't be banned.
While erotica teases,
It tastefully pleases.
Curators retain the whip hand.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Our new gym teacher reeks of virility.
He is awesome—such strength and agility!
He wins staff admiration
And kids' adulation—
A model of formidability.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
"Dear John," the brief letter began.
"I'm in love with a wonderful man.
While I know you're at war,
Please, my dear, don't be sore.
I love him and not you. Your ex, Dan."

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
Said a mason, face down in his mastic,
"Some measures I'll take that are drastic,
As this fast drying grout
Has done ate up my snout.
I will get me a surgeon that's plastic."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
All the rumors about her were bad,
Like she slept with her brother and dad.
Still, she ended her life
As a dutiful wife,
And the mother of eight, I might add.

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
Dieffenbachia, popular plant:
Grown indoors it's a beauty, I'll grant.
But I nibbled on some;
Now it seems I'm struck dumb —
I would tell you some more, but I can't.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Clearly butter cuts easily when
The kitchen's a hundred and ten.
Make the knife super hot,
Then the butter you've got
Will be cut by the weakest of men.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Would a ceder accede and agree
To an order, command, or decree
To succeed as a seeder
(Not follow the leader)
And plant a new cedarwood tree?

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
It's spring, and the garden chores beckon.
Time for planting my herbs now, I reckon.
Got my seeds and my hoe —
What?! It's starting to snow??
It is April 10th? Yeah? Just checkin'...

limerick_list.author: AronKuppersmith
limerick_list.text:
Linda, Denny and Paul's record spun.
It's the Wings album Band on the Run.
They jammed such a hot set.
Fans love "Bluebird" and "Jet",
And the title track hit number one.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
It's enough to confuse and befuddle
And bother me, mix up and muddle
My mind and then jerk me
Around, really irk me!
You wanna make love or just cuddle?

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
My other co-workers revile 'em,
But me, I just process and file 'em.
They govern our day
So much, you could say
That the lunatics run this asylum.

limerick_list.author: Benton Randall Olmsted
limerick_list.text:
To create the archetypical thriller,
Mr. Hitchcock devised that the killer
Should mostly be clever
And above all should never
Be played by an actor named Stiller.

limerick_list.author: pöt
limerick_list.text:
I'm environment-conscious: I eat
Fruit and veggies galore, but no meat,
And I cycle (no car!),
No matter how far;
Commuting by bike is a treat.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
The bout she envisioned was whirling
About, with her petticoats swirling,
And dancing till morn—
So her husband was torn,
Since the bout he envisioned was curling.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The word face can refer to cosmetics,
As in dealing with facial esthetics.
When Anne "puts on her face,"
She puts make-up in place.
It has nothing to do with prosthetics.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
"If you miss this last game-winning basket,"
The coach said, "I won't blow a gasket.
I'll just rip out your heart,
Tear your body apart,
And then bury your bits in a casket."

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Although Mother Nature's polluted,
The culprits are mostly ill-suited
To act when she's dirty:
Men rightly get shirty
When pressed to keep mothers abluted.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I love bees, both the honey and bumble,
But the honeybee's best.  I feel humble
'Cause I take all their honey
And don't pay them money,
And they buzz—but they don't ever grumble.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Princeton Press dummied up my new book
To show ad men just how it will look.
"Solid gold!" they're declaring,
"Provocative! Daring!"
(And other such gobbledygook).

limerick_list.author: DenmarK
limerick_list.text:
The Copernican model does not
Put the Earth in the middle. That's what
Was once thought — how archaic,
With wheels Ptolemaic —
Not the Sun-centred system we've got.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Though his surrogates cover his tracks,
His involvement's revealed through the cracks.
At the root of this, we
See his fingerprints.  He
Has his hand in this plot to the max.

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
Arthropathy (joint-type disease)
Is causing sharp pains in my knees.
But the pills that I take
For the ache also make
My poor heart beat in twos and in threes.

limerick_list.author: mino
limerick_list.text:
"Schtop zis singing! You must! I insist!"
Screeched Frau Dietrich, whilst shaking her fist.
"Dummkopf, I sing ze song;
Meanvile you play along!
Zat is vot an accompanist ist!"

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
Miss Custis wed Robert E. Lee.
"He seemed just like my cup of tea.
Such choices that faced me,
I had to act — chastely —
'Fore other girls saw what I see."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
This is cultic behavior you're showing—
That tail and those horns that you're growing.
Go ahead, join a cult,
But beware the result:
Any chance to be saved you'll be blowing.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
The Wizard of Oz made a city
Of emerald green. Oh, how pretty!
It's like grandma's mint sauce,
Or like Brussels sprouts, moss,
Or  dill pickles (great big; itty-bitty).

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
"Are you worried we're nearing the night?
To take photos, it should be quite bright."
"Through this plastic enclosure,
We determine exposure
By a meter that measures the light."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
It's a constant political game
That the Democrats play.  They're to blame
For our woes, which is why
I won't vote for the guy
Or the gal with a "D" by their name.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Does the Taj Mahal give you a kick?
I'll disclose its strange origin quick:
It was built to perfection,
The largest erection
A guy ever got for a chick.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I'm exhausted; I'm sure I'll flake out —
Just like that, fall asleep, there's no doubt.
Much allure you're outpouring,
But soon I'll be snoring,
Too tired to even make out.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The Washington Post had a star
Dubbed the Style Invitational Czar.
He created a contest,
A humor-savant test,
For pun-loving wordsmiths to spar.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
The ad cost us six thousand bucks,
But the cost of each mille is the crux.
So for twelve thousand views,
That's five hundred we lose
For each thousand who know that it sucks.

limerick_list.author: geniuswaitress
limerick_list.text:
At the office, a young CPA
Came costumed as Lady Jane Grey.
"Afternoon, Mr Lee."
"How'd you know it was me?"
"Um... you wear that same dress every day."

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
If you're frightened, then maybe your blood'll
Either crudle or curdle or cruddle;
Though this may seem absurd,
They are all the same word,
But the spelling's got into a muddle.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
Every one of us thinks, I suppose,
