I studied and learned  crystal structure.
His chemistry teaching
Was deep and far-reaching,
And now I rejoice in its fructure.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
If a woman's official vocation
Is commander in chief of the nation,
Then the Army must do
What she's telling them to.
What a broad overgeneralization!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Job and school, at my mother's insistence,
Are both ten miles from home (equidistance),
But the fact I like least:
One's due west; one's due east.
It's the bane of my teenage existence.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
On my sickbed I lay, just a kid.
Before into a coma I slid,
My dad lovingly spoke —
Told a gut-busting joke.
I thought I'd die laughing. I did.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Hmmm.  A snack to enhance my Campari.
To the waiter, "What's this?" "Well, I'm sorry.
Though really a squid
(I'm not kidding you, kid),
It sounds better if called calamari."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Her classes iñ Spañish iñstilled a
Preteñsioñ iñ studeñt Bruñhilde:
She imagiñes it's highbrow
To add oñ añ eyebrow
To every last Ñ, with a tilde.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
"Your emporium, sir, I find lacking,
Since your logic has nary a backing."
"Are you saying my brain
Needs an update? Insane!
I think you, sir, could do with a whacking!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
"My plan's working.  I wouldn't advise
Changing horses midstream; it's unwise.
You'd be filled with remorse
If you altered our course."
So we listened then watched our demise.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The Candida albicans plan:
To discomfit each woman and man.
No if, buts, or maybes—
It starts when we're babies.
Cancel candida? Can we? We can!

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
A Yorkshireman thought it a sin:
His wife's headstone said, "Lord, she was thin".
To the mason, said he,
"You have left off the e!"
At "Eeh Lord, she was thin" now we grin.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
An old prospector kept all his tools
Inside croker sacks tied on his mules.
When I asked, "Why not ride?"
He replied, "Once I tried,
But the pick gouged my family jewels."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The grand marshal's a job that seems fun.
At parades he's the big #1.
But now here is the thing:
They do not let him bring
Any handcuffs, his horse, or a gun.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
Yes, autonomy's good if you're grown,
Independent and out on your own.
To stand tall on your feet
So the world you can meet
Means that far from the coop you have flown.

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
A demarche is a statement of views
To a public official, with cues
As to what is desired,
Maybe what is required.
(It's hoped they're not asking for coups!)

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Lest it roll off and drop to the ground,
A good carpenter's pencil's not round.
It's squared off or it's flat
And you know where it's at:
Where you parked it, still readily found.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
That Arabian camel whose hump
Was the size of an elephant's rump—
Since her last liposuction
(Elective reduction)
It's down to a lemon-sized lump.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When I'm making my floral selections
For ladies who share my affections,
"Biacuminate, please,"
I will ask for, since these
Have two points but in different directions.

limerick_list.author: Reia Light
limerick_list.text:
In Florence, Marseilles, and Milan,
The Black Death sent most everyone on
To hell or to heaven,
'Round 1347.
Before long, half of Europe was gone.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It appears that, for good or for bad,
He's the spit, not the image of Dad—
Who's a redhead, and proud
Of his counter, this loud
Little dribble-faced, towheaded tad.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
My memory's short. I'm a fish.
Just to swim and find food is my wish.
I forget — was I taught
To avoid getting caught?
Oh, my memory's short; I'm a ... hmm.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Twin actors, whose surname is Phelps,
Play the Weasley twins — red-headed whelps.
Seen the films? — Harry Potter?
If you haven't, you've gotta!
Read the books first; it magically helps.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
A decursion? Not there by that fire.
They're just sober folks filed 'round a pyre.
Not a group bearing arms
That would set off alarms.
Merely mourners, some kin, some for hire.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Affective is one of those notions
Concerned with arousing emotions
Which tend to create
A hysterical state
Wherein tears are produced in great oceans.

limerick_list.author: creelbm
limerick_list.text:
Cesium 133's oscillation
Is used to define the duration
Of a second.  This base
Block of time on the face
Of a clock needs no more explanation.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
I doubt that the typical man knows
What the musical-instrument fan knows:
When fingers are pushin',
A bolster's the cushion
That deadens the sound in pianos.

limerick_list.author: eris8x6
limerick_list.text:
An expatriate abdal named Grant
Moved to Persia, and now, with a chant,
In a skirt with a flare
And his arms in the air,
He majestically whirls till he can't.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Dis ya car dat youse wants to be towed?
I'll hook up. Get you offa da road.
You don't got Triple A?
Den big bucks you must pay
And in cash. We don' like bein owed.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Diacaustics are making me drool;
I am floating face-down in my pool.
I am limned in bright lines,
Making dancing designs,
And my shadow is totally cool!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
John of Norfolk said, "What I've been told
Is the king's been betrayed, like for gold.
My great liege, friend and master
Is facing disaster;
King Richard the Third's bought and sold!"

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
"If you leave out the normal conjunctions,"
Said Pete, "then your sentence still functions.
It's asyndeton's aim
In this lexical game,
As in: 'railway tracks, meeting points, junctions'."

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
When the time of his passing drew near,
Young King Edward the Sixth was sincere:
In the year '53
He succumbed to TB,
Expressing his faith, and not fear.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
For the Christians in Rome, persecution
Underwent bad-to-worse evolution.
Thus affirmed Diocletian:
"I'll outdo measures Decian!"
But he failed to achieve retribution.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Moving here was one stupid mistake—
So inhumanly hot, for God's sake,
It could sauté your brain.
Man, I'd murder for rain.
In this hellhole, I'm just gonna bake.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dana's first to speak out on the plights
Of the victims of animal rites.
(He invented the horse
And made millions, of course.)
Now for animal rights Dana fights.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
It's confirmed; we've just tallied the get:
This year's fair's the most lucrative yet.
While the "food police" fumed,
All the eats were consumed.
(Chuchi's chili's still making me sweat.)

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Overcome by a bad bronchiolar
Disease was an avid young bowler.
The second-hand smoke
At the lanes made him croak.
Now an angel, he's one holy roller.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
On my Chesterfield, sprawling like Nero,
I'm a dressing-gowned, gin-sipping hero.
Such a deep-cushioned sofa's
Ideal for us loafers,
Whose interest in working's near zero.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This verse is a tad academical:
A dihydrate is made when a chemical
Joins molecules, two—
Yes, of water. It's true,
And my statement's plain fact, not polemical.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I believe I can play this role fully,
Like that film star, the great Monty Woolley.
This character's bag
Is his proneness to brag
When he drinks. He's a Drawcansir (bully).

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
My acquisitiveness has direction:
Arctophily shows my affection.
Teddy bears were my joy
As a very small boy,
And I now have a massive collection.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
Has that Chanticleer romanced the chickens?
Have those biddies become easy pickin's?
Candle eggs with a light—
There are signs there, all right,
That that rooster's been raising the dickens!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The choragus today is a reader
Whose powerful voice makes this pleader
The chorus's star
In our stark and bizarre
German tragedy, Follow the Lieder.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
Making books is a bindery chore;
Ordinarily paper, galore,
Is fastened together —
Some with backs (rarely leather),
As were bound back in book days of yore.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
On your aglet I ogle a figure.
This baby's engraved and no bigger
Than a button — how quaint!
Does it show me a saint?
Or an angel? or Christ? Oh, it's Tigger!

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Richie's stock market plunge missed its mark,
When his "sure-fire" shares all went dark.
His portfolio's no more,
And now Rich is dirt-poor.
Where's he live?  At, it's said, bushy-park.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Our computers fulfill every need;
They do math with incredible speed.
They can animate comics—
What's next? Autonomics?
Can they actually translate and read?

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
Teach your children—each time that you might—
Things are seldom all wrong or all right;
It's okay if you say
There are levels of gray,
And that life isn't just black and white.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
A newspaper writer named Marty
Penned a weekly critique of the arty.
But his views were refused
By The News, which accused
Him of joining the Columnist Party.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My pacifist friends think me screwy,
And react to my feelings with: "Phooey!"
But I'm dewy-eyed when
I remember the men
Who were heroes, like Admiral Dewey.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
An acarid—mightn't he bite,
A mite hungry for blood in the night?
Take a stab and predict:
Might we get mighty ticked
When afflicted? We very well might.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
There's no food on this raft. Are we cursed
To succumb to starvation and thirst?
We're all in the same boat
And we're hungry; let's vote
To find out who I start eating first.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
In a baby, physicians agree
That abdominal defects can be
Where some organs may fall
Or protrude through the wall;
An exomphalos there we will see.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
At the Halloween party I'm fab;
Clothed in yellow I couldn't be drab.
But they all miss my joke.
(Could my meter be broke?)
Why won't somebody call me a cab?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Avant-gardism's big in the arts.
It's a school of ideas that departs
From traditional norms
To establish new forms—
Redefining what speaks to our hearts.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
I love Carmen, composed by Bizet;
It's a masterful work. Though he may
Have passed on without knowing,
This story keeps glowing
With passion and drama. Olé!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I've invented the best-tasting candy bar —
And its size is just right! What a dandy bar!
It's a no-flour sweet
In a hand-shape that's neat
And compact, so I call it a "HandiBar".

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
It's the nightingale, not yet the lark,
That is singing out there in the park.
We've no moon, cloudy skies,
And we'll soon hear the sighs
Of a pair's love affair in the dark.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Your sense of decorum was dashed
When a moth crawled from out your mustache.
As you bowed to the Queen,
Your discomfort was keen.
What you felt at the time was abashed.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Epithelialisation's innate.
Skin healing time often's not great.
Let such wounds have some air.
Treat their scabs with great care,
And new skin will grow there, no debate.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Birdie sweetly sings songs—pretty thing
Flies around on (chirp) feathery wing
(Chirp, chirp) spreading its cheer
And that bird flu, we hear.
(Chirp) "Beware, folks, beware!" it'll sing.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
"I've some snails to ship home," I told Fred.
Got some cartons and painted them red.
And then I applied
A white "S" to each side.
"Now they'll know it's 'S' cargo," I said.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
E-commerce is how I define
Transactions of mine that combine
Trading, selling or buying
With the Net. No denying
I'm livin' la vida online!

limerick_list.author: David Schildkret
limerick_list.text:
A bravo's  a fancy-pants hit man.
You hope he's a physically fit man
(A mean desperado
Who's full of bravado),
Unless he's decided you're it, man.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Canny cannibals deem it effete
To eat parts of themselves (What conceit!)
With their forearms or calves,
They go at it by halves;
They don't find autophagia a treat.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Assemblages show us how art
Can be made from a cast-off spare part,
And a rusty old spring,
And all that kind of thing…
Then you sell it for millions — that's smart.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
My existence wage keeps me alive,
But you can't really say that I thrive.
Though I've somewhere to stay,
And I eat every day,
I earn barely enough to survive.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
A role model, always reliable,
John was one of our best, exemplifiable,
Till he came into work
With that gun — went berserk!
That he'd changed overnight's undeniable.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This family's not very nice.
Stay away from them—that's my advice.
On the fin or the tail
Of a dolphin or whale
Are Cyamidae—whales' nasty lice.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I've a check and a photo ID;
Still the grocery clerk asks to see
Some additional proof
To confirm it's no spoof.
What a cashable check this will be!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
So you figure I'm no competition.
You're expecting to get my position.
Think again, you can't win;
I'm entrenched and dug in:
A perennial human tradition.

limerick_list.author: bestswanbird
limerick_list.text:
With no guts of its own it may make
Its abode inside yours, and partake
Of the food you've digested.
You're cestode-infested:
So tired, and with innards that ache.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
There's the gnateater, found in Brazil,
And the pangolin, Africa. Chill
With the slender salamander
Then stop for a gander
At the rosefish for black-bellied thrill.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
So deep is accounting's ennui
That choosing a method can be
(If asked with panache,
"Accrual or cash?")
Mistaken for glib repartee.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Equivocalness is confusing.
It's vagueness an author is choosing,
So his words are misleading.
When his method's succeeding,
He may judge the result is amusing.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
"At the mint," said a worker named Lennie,
"A cupreous coin is our penny,
But they're almost all zinc —
Not what most people think.
We've now two hundred billion — so many!"

limerick_list.author: otherwisefine
limerick_list.text:
You're not such a bad sort of bloke,
But your cricketing skills are a joke.
You first lift up the bat
But then leave it at that.
Such a backlift should augur a stroke!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
You're quite the nonsensical chap,
And you're causing our patience to snap,
So we're no longer buying
Your whimsical lying.
We want it to stop: cut the crap.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Biota's a term that's assigned
To the flora and fauna combined.
Individual lions
Or scallions are bions;
A man, not the whole of mankind.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
We'd describe a big circle with string,
Then each kid put a frog in the ring.
As they hopped we'd all shout,
And each name was called out.
Then the champ of them all was dubbed "King."

limerick_list.author: Workshop and Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Appetitions are longings that pique:
Prehend shivam, for goodness you seek;
You're driven by duty
Towards sundaram (beauty)
And satyam (the truth, so to speak).

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
It's a drummond, a sure thing, I know.
With this scheme, mate, our fortunes will grow.
No words could be truer.
Success as secure
As funds banked with Drummond & Co.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Wedding rings, emblematically seen,
Are symbols on fingers which mean
Endless love, I suppose.
Selfsame ring through my nose?
That's an emblem on which I'm not keen!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Just how far is an arm's length away?
If you stretch can you reach it, or nay?
When they claim with a grin
"You're an armshot within,"
Are they pulling your leg, so to say?

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Colporrhaphy sutures assaults
Made by trauma to vaginal vaults,
Inner walls, and introitus
By labor and coitus
And mends some congenital faults.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
With the pagans invaidan, blockaidan,
At Bamburgh all hope was fast faidan,
But faith was displaidan
The prayers so persuaidan
Of Aidan, evaidan a raidan.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
That's a drum table, folks, 'cause it's round,
Like a snare drum without that great sound.
Look, the apron has drawers
For the small things one stores.
It's the best Duncan Phyfe style we've found.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
In her outhouse she sat, calmly knitting;
Constipation had caused longish sitting.
When a feller's bad chop
Caused his huge ax to drop
On her housetop, she popped: "My head's splitting."

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Jack is anal-retentive, I fear.
His dislike of disorder? Severe!
Should he change Didi's didee,
He folds it so tidy
No hint of what's plopped will appear.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Diseasedness, meaning "morbidity,"
Can remit or get worse with rapidity.
You may sicken on Sunday,
Feel better on Monday,
Then Tuesday show morbid rigidity.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What moves when you're starting to hustle,
Or find yourself caught in a tussle?
Think of actinin—it
Is the protein that's fit
To produce the contraction in muscle.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
On my low-growing camomile lawn,
Where I danced in the nude until dawn,
My dear wife gives to me
Calming camomile tea
Laced with Prozac; I grin as I yawn.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
An ambitious ex-rancher prayed, "Please,
Make me top apiarian." He's
A success as of late,
And he brags, "Life is great.
I've a million or more head of bees!"

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
You have heard of disloyal Macbeth
And the man he had put to his death.
To the victory roast
Came a banqueter ghost.
It was Banquo who'd drawn his last breath.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
I'm relieved that I earned my BD,
But divinity school's not for me.
I prayed only for grades;
Never took off my shades—
Think for grad school I'll try MIT.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
There is one with your name on, they say,
And in war zones it might come your way.
But no bullet can know
Who I am — where to go —
For it hasn't been given my na...

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Oh, she'll hunt — see, she snuffles around:
Goes about with her nose to the ground.
Rub her snout in a kill
And she's blooded — her skill
Will emerge. It's her pedigree: hound.

limerick_list.author: JakeVortex
limerick_list.text:
In this byte here all eight of them sit
For you see that each one is a bit.
An encoding decides
Right where each bit abides.
Though once Chaucer would write it "abit".

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Glenda Phelps's face lit up with glee:
"Gleeful Glenda's the new name for me!
Always merry and bright,
I'm a constant delight."
Others cried at the wake, but not she!

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
You want to know what's in a conto?
I'll tell you in confidence pronto:
A thousand escudos,
And savers accrued those
In Portugal—not in Toronto.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Big leaguer: It's every boy's dream
To play ball for his favorite team.
And the boys who are older?
That dream will still smolder —
Their eyes have that MVP gleam.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Imagine the trunk of a tree
With two branches; my brother and me
Are dicephalus twins —
At the neck he begins.
I'm a bum.  Oddly, he's an M.D.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The American Bible Society
Prints bibles in such a variety
Of tongues.  They infuse
All the Earth with Good News
To assist the expansion of piety.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Cool and clumsy,  and round as a quail,
God's experiment: fated to fail!
Might this large, passive meal
Have dodged slaughter? Get real!
Dopy dodos would never prevail.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The cartulary holds all the deeds
And the copies of charters he needs
To divide the estate
And decide on the fate
Of her baubles and bangles and beads.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Your regime calls its scheme commonsensible.
It's efficient, but hardly defensible:
Genocidal "solutions"
With mass executions
Will someday be judged reprehensible.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
When I brushed up against him today,
Touching lightly while passing his way,
And I noticed him blush,
I was caught in a rush
Of excitement and feeling risqué.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
"Your Honour, I killed mum and dad,
But think on these words that I add:
Have mercy, be mild;
I'm a poor orphan child." —
That's chutzpah, the nerve of a cad.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
On an earth orbit drawn round the sun,
In a near-perfect circle we're spun.
(It's elliptical, though,
As close measurements show.)
In one year (that's twelve months) the trip's done.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
Cars don't crash; there's no nudity shown;
Out of windows no bad guys get thrown—
No, a screenplay must slough
Off extraneous stuff
When becoming a film by Bresson.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The maiden whose suitor was neuter
Replied that he simply won't suit her,
And refused to engage.
So, abused, in a rage,
He shot back that his aim's now to shoot her.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Bathybius: thought for a time
As life's source, a primordial slime.
Huxley pled to a goof,
Once convinced by the proof
That his slime was far short of sublime.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
How I love a nice hot chicken liver!
Just one bite sets my taste  buds a-quiver!
Whether boiled or fried,
I could solely subside
On these treats! The delight makes me shiver!

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
I have baited my hook and I wait—
C'mon, baby, come nibble my bait!
Bait's a part of attraction.
With pheromone action,
Some cologne may just hook me a date.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Though it's heavy, and yellow, and cool,
There's no riches 'round here, as a rule.
I don't mean to be mean,
But the streak is dark green:
Chalcopyrite is gold for a fool.

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
Near the Broad Street pump, folk started dying
When cholera hit them. Defying
His peers, Doctor Snow
Had them stop the pump's flow,
Showing water at fault, no denying.

limerick_list.author: kandabongo
limerick_list.text:
Many aurar make one Swedish krona,
Which means zip when I shop in Pomona.
And anyway, cash
Ain't essential; just dash
Once you've got what you want. Signed, Winona.

limerick_list.author: Suzanne Kreul
limerick_list.text:
Said the convict regarding his cell,
"I won't acclimate here very well.
I will never adjust
To the damp or the dust
Or the winks of my cellmate from Hell."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Rich desserts I incessantly seek.
I'm a French pastry freak, so to speak.
Filled with custard or fruit,
They're so bon, no dispute,
Or, in other words, très magnifique!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's a rumor I'm fearing is true
'Bout your wife and a large kangaroo
Checking in to an inn
For a weekend of sin.
I'd check into that soon, were I you.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Raising children has left me dead beat!
And my legs are so weary. This heat!
Bring my footstool, my dear,
The small, low one — it's clear
I should use it for raising my feet.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
When farmers' cats wander away
Off into the fields, become stray,
And grow feral, or wild,
They are often reviled.
They're killing off songbirds! Oy vey.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
"Your projector might fail," warned the geek,
"So be chary, preparing to speak."
"Before giving my talk,
I could check on the chalk,"
Chuckled Chuck, who was chock full of cheek.

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
Awesome is something exalted,
While awful is terribly faulted
And wrong, like a run of
Bad jokes (like the one of
Two peanuts, and one was assaulted).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
She'd a  breathtaking décolletage—
So much glamour, she seemed a mirage.
And it took me two hours
Just to pin on her flowers:
A corsage for her lovely corsage.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Have a car and my clothes without fail
Outside of this old county jail.
It has only one fence,
 Which does not make much sense,
So tomorrow I'll scale it and bail.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Sweet Juliet has of late been pursued
By young Paris, one cereous dude
Who seems sculpted of wax.
He stops maids in their tracks!
But he knows it. The dude has got 'tude.

limerick_list.author: Fleur De Lim
limerick_list.text:
Leaves of gray and, at times, silver-white,
Luminescent by day and at night,
If with water you fill 'er,
The drenched dusty miller
Turns green, like a bean. What a sight!

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
He once worked as a tough nightclub bouncer:
Security guard, rowdy trouncer.
But now he's top pastor,
A cardinal master:
Pope Francis, a Rome-based pronouncer.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
At an art fair (with no hints of sales),
At the stall of the young Prince of Wales:
"Dearest Charles, it is known
You are heir to the throne;
Have you nothing but old prints of whales?"

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
When he fell on his sword, id est died,
Cleopatra, his lover, then cried,
"Hic jacet a Marcus
Antonius carcase,"
Soon prostrate, per asp, at his side.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Your motives, deep down, are perverse,
Self-aggrandizing, reckless and worse —
Fundamentally wrong!
Still, I may go along.
It's that part about "lining my purse."

limerick_list.author: Snowy Owl
limerick_list.text:
I once was symmetrical, matched;
Then my branch felt an itch, so I scratched.
Now my beautiful bark
Has a cicatrix mark
Where that bothersome leaf was attached.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Narrow guidelines cross every fresh page
In your notebook: a handwriting guage.
There are lines? Almost ain't,
As they're printed so faint.
I'll admit feint's their name, at this stage!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
If you're looking for something to nibble,
Use a digging stick (also called dibble).
Ancient cultures have found:
Shove this stick in the ground,
Pull up roots—maybe not—I won't quibble.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
I said, "Make me some vats out of wood,"
But these foeders will do me no good,
Since you can't age your beer
In a vat that's veneer.
(My instructions were misunderstood.)

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Captain Komet has plans for the moon,
Spanning craters with domes very soon:
"Earthmen won't feel at home in
This place till there's domin',
And first comes a lunar saloon."

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
When chromium's chromous, its fate
Is to have a less oxidised state
Than the highly charged chromic
That gives the Suomic
(Read: "Finnish") of chromium plate.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Frilly skirts and high kicks their career,
The dancers were met with a cheer.
In the wings, Jacques stopped dozing —
Critiqued his composing:
"For the cancan I'm Offenbach here."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
First the general sharpened his blade.
Then he turned to his aide and he bade
That he start persecution
Of every Confucian.
Crusade? No, a troop dragonnade.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
The penguin, a comical bird,
Had a name that is now rarely heard,
And, although not polite,
It described him just right.
It was arsefoot, an old sailor word.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Use comedic for comic? A gaffe
Say the Pedant Police of our staff.
The distinction is slight.
If you're up for a fight,
Only comic is what makes you laugh.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
At St. Mary's, I tried to be tactful
As I preached, since the pews were all packed full
Of the deeply devout:
"Please, your boob's hanging out,
Sister Anne, and it's highly distractful."

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Let us sign this historic entente.
We've had plenty of time to think on't.
"It's a new understanding
That's fair, undemanding —
The friendly agreement all want."

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
While team batting was thought to be grave,
Their defense stirs the fans: "Do the wave!"
Their closer has fanned
Every foe in the land
Of the "D" and the home of the save.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
A gambrel roof—we give this name
To a roof wherein this is the aim:
The pitch of each slope
Has two gradients. The hope?
Greater headroom obtained 'neath its frame.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles and speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
We use centi- for point-oh-one meters;
On occasion, it's point-oh-one liters.
But the bug that you meet
Having point-oh-one feet
Has encountered some centipede eaters.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
If to mental disorders you're prone,
There's treatment.  Just get on the phone
To a shrink, who's the link
To get thinking in sync
By prescribing butyrophenone.

limerick_list.author: Dottie
limerick_list.text:
Little Ali and Ellie, the twins,
Look the same; they're alike as two pins.
If I ask which is El,
Will they tell? Will they hell!
I just know that they're Phelpses, not Flynns.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My girlfriend is charming and sweet;
She's allective from hairdo to feet,
Which means she's alluring.
I found the word during
My quest for the quaint obsolete.

limerick_list.author: John Wellington Wells
limerick_list.text:
It's the old adiabolist claim
That the devil is only a name.
He doesn't exist,
So you shouldn't insist
That he made you ring up an old flame.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Her dentist is making a sheath
That she'll wear, with her tongue tucked beneath,
In her mouth when she's sleeping—
For bruxism—keeping
My daughter from grinding her teeth.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
A gopher, exceedingly thorough,
Finds a field's most felicitous furrow.
It's a suitable start;
Time to practice his art —
To claw through the earth and to burrow.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
He's magnanimous in his defeats,
And gracious to those that he beats.
His acclaim is his due;
He deserves to win through
(Excepting the times that he cheats).

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
The protein colipase displays
Stuff that chemicals do nights and days:
It floats around loose
In your pancreas juice,
And helps lipase in ways that amaze.

limerick_list.author: splendiferous
limerick_list.text:
A limerick must have its beats:
Its apt anapestic repeats.
So a limericist who
Has no rhythm is due
For efforts that meet with defeats.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Kids, I've brought in some hedgehogs today
To present a hedgehoggy display.
It's conclusively shown
They're collectively known
By one word. What's that noun? It's array.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"I was told that you're dating a mystic.
Do you find," I inquired, "he's sadistic?"
"Not at all. The guy's kind,
But can't make up his mind.
His opinions I find aoristic."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Coincidentally, my son has big feet
As does Marvin, who lives down the street.
It's coincidence, sure,
Since my wife's chaste and pure,
And assures me she never would cheat.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Young boys and young girls like to play
Both with toys and each other, I'd say.
Elder boys playing games
With most beautiful dames
See fair game in fair ladies, for prey.

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
The manservant, loyal and true,
Had a fling with the maid and then flew.
She declared, "I'm with child!"
And completely went wild—
"I was buttled, by God, in the loo!"

limerick_list.author: Rudi
limerick_list.text:
Inasmuch as you're known as a fumbler,
Perhaps you could be a bit humbler.
Whatever you state,
Your playing's not "great,"
So stop whining and don't be a grumbler.

limerick_list.author: Seth Brown
limerick_list.text:
Said the boss, "Just stay quiet, have class,"
But you had to go squeal on his ass.
 Now your bigmouthed mistake
 Means you'll land in the lake,
Where your friends will be bigmouthed — like bass.

limerick_list.author: Chavi Beck
limerick_list.text:
I'm a midnight-oil-burning machine;
Cups of coffee galore keep me keen.
Now I'm sleepless in bed
With an ache in my head—
Could it be I've had too much caffeine?

limerick_list.author: David Schildkret
limerick_list.text:
My boogying's awkward at best,
So if you want to dance, be my guest.
For when I hit the floor,
People head for the door
Or at least suggest, "Give it a rest."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The name Acme is one of those brands
Geared to shoppers' peculiar demands.
If you trust those cartoons
On TV afternoons,
They make anvils and huge rubber bands.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
It's a hubbub, a brouhaha. Cowed?
It'll join any anapest crowd.
Need an end-rhyme? Ta-daa!
It becomes brouhaha.
And brouhaha is also allowed.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Asks Daltrey of Townshend, "Can you
Find a drummer to add to our crew?"
"Roger that!" answers Pete,
"I hear Moon has the beat."
So it's Keith, then, who's cast in The Who.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
As a fencer, I duel each day.
Should you cross me, you'd best drop and pray.
Let me catch you off guard
And I'll  come at you hard,
Armed with cutlass—no wussy epee.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
The Ascendancy Irish were bodies
Of Planters, at first merely squaddies.
King James, then the Scots,
And King William sent lots
Of them over as land-grabbing Proddies.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This nefarious business must stop.
They should lock up the guy at the top.
There's a chop shop in town;
Stolen cars it breaks down.
Guess it's time that I spoke to a cop.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
A carnivorous dinosaur said,
"Go away, or I'll bite off your head.
See, I love to eat meat
And you're tender and sweet.
If you don't run, you soon will be dead!"

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
Watch his followers riot and rave,
Each to outworn beliefs still a slave.
Could he see their acts goonish,
Wild and mindless — cartoonish —
Mohammed might spin in his grave.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Every weblog, each thread and each post,
Left to right, pole to pole, coast to coast,
All share a huge unity,
A "cyber-community
Of thought."  That's the blogosphere's boast.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
This banana republic is run
By a colonel, a man of the gun.
Caudillismo's the rule,
And he suffers no fool.
He's the one who decides what gets done.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I'm responsible, keeping an ear
To events, so blame me if I steer
This great country astray.
I'll not scapegoat — no way.
I'm Commander.  The buck?  It stops here.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
In Saxony's Schneeberg you'll find it:
The atelestite crystal. They've mined it.
The word's from the Greek,
Unaccomplished; don't seek
Any source, as there's none known behind it.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
A man at my bar, when he's high,
Blows the foam from his beer in my eye.
I could rip him to shreds
Over his lager heads;
I'm at loggerheads now with this guy.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
The Cliftonia grow to small trees,
A ways up from the Florida Keys.
In the springtime they bloom
With a gentle perfume—
And the bee-keepers pleasure their bees.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
That woman is frumpy and dumpy
And has cottage cheese thighs—they are lumpy
And dimpled.  Oh, well.
I've been dry for a spell
In the love game.  "What say?  Rumpy-pumpy?"

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
The checkerbloom's common along
Grassy trails in the west, growing strong
Near a high mountain slope
Where some shade gives it scope,
As it blooms in a pink, lacy throng.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Beaten eggs, milk and spice mixed with bread,
And then fried in a pan and then spread
With sweet syrup or jam —
Scarf it down, and then BAM!
For my tummy, French toast is like lead.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Broken windows in winter,"  swears Wes,
"Make me wish for a warmer address.
When it's twenty below
And those frigid winds blow,
It's as cold as a witch's caress."

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
That breve rest (just two measures) Jack guessed
Seemed too long, so he thought it was best
On that rest not to dwell.
Maestro gave him much hell:
"Those resisting a rest I detest!"

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
While long favored, this birch tar, as glue,
The stuff's also a sweet-smelling chew.
And as daggett, on leather,
It protects in damp weather.
We forget it's essentially goo.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
A dag is, with people, inept —
Maybe nerdy. The word hasn't kept
Its original sense
Of a (don't take offense)
Tough eccentric—but one we accept.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
When an emerald has flaws showing through,
A skilled gemcutter knows what to do:
Watch him cut and refine
Leaving eight sides that shine.
P.S. Diamonds are cut this way too.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work and Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Your blood (and the platelets it's got),
When it's donated, helps out a lot
With coagulative ills
Of a nature that kills
When a patient has blood that won't clot.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Yes, cystostomy—that's what you need
If from pain you would wish to be freed.
The urologist's goal?
In your bladder, a hole
To drain urine.  Now let us proceed.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Rise each day at first light, and be firm
In your stance.  Then, alert to the germ
Of success, you will show
You're entitled to crow:
"It's the early bird catches the worm!"

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
The exchange rate's not really profound:
It's, in finance, the quantity bound
To be issued by banks
Dealing pesos or francs
When you give them a dollar or pound.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Derivation of astrogate's clear
From its roots: it's a star that you steer.
Navigation guides ships
(Navis: Latin. No quips!)
But it means "guide a starship", I fear.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
I created a boxplot that showed
Just the median (no mean or mode)
Of the data I entered,
With quartiles off-centered,
And whiskers for me to decode.

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
Bowling figures: with these you are told
Of the overs that each player bowled,
The amount that were maiden
(Which means run-unladen),
Runs conceded, and wickets they hold.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Do you see what the hell John is tagging?
A dragon (Komodo), tail wagging!
Low on brains, high on brawn,
The guy's zeal's welded "ON" —
Never saw his butt flagging (that's dragging)!

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
"This game of croquet is absurd,"
Said my wife. "I've a game that's preferred."
So she put up a net,
Got the badminton set,
Raised a racquet and whacked it—the bird.

limerick_list.author: natelevin
limerick_list.text:
This is all mush and milk, if you please!
A slight puff, not a really stiff breeze!
With constant reworking,
And picking, and clerking,
It's bland—my once strong, stinky cheese!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
You've a fungal infection? That's rich!
Chromoblastomycosis? A bitch!
I'll be spreading the word
Right away: "Have you heard?
Joe's got warts on his legs and they itch!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
At least four different plants make this claim:
Dusty miller, they say, is their name.
And two players of fame
Who called baseball their game
Used the name Dusty Miller—the same!

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"From the Greek, class, today's word: echinus.
Define it, please. Now then, no shyness."
"On Ionian pillars,
They're curvy carved fillers?"
"Dear, Doric's the order (A-)."

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Simply confident, that's my old mom;
She has cool self-assurance: aplomb.
No fear leaves her numb
Or impedes her aplomb —
Mum stands straight as a plumb-bob, and calm.

limerick_list.author: Tom Foolery
limerick_list.text:
What is used to entice is called bait,
Which to place in the water and wait
Is a pastime held high
In regard, though just why
No one's ever been able to state.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
King of brothels?  I cannot deny I am.
I gave builders a rough bubble diagram:
"Garden here. Hot tubs there.
There a chapel for prayer."
(That last item shows what kind of guy I am.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Ol' Man Horne lost his crop (that's a sad thing)
While bedding five ladies (a glad thing).
It's when horny old goats
Go to sow their wild oats
That a crop failure's not such a bad thing!

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Noble head of a lion ("Nice kitty!")
On the body of goat isn't pretty.
Add the tail from a snake?
What a mess you would make!
Send that monster right back to committee!

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
We have similar looks, me and Ike;
Corresponding; resemblant; alike.
It's a cross I can't bear,
Though I doubt I would care
If he wasn't a Pollicle tyke.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
There's a canvas that's blank on my easel.
The size of my customers' fees'll
Decide what I paint,
And you'll hear no complaint.
Want a diesel? A saint? Or a weasel?

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
An Arabian lad named Aziz
Brought the rival Rashid to their knees.
A mere youth, this ameer
Would a nation endear,
And his heirs lived a life full of ease.

limerick_list.author: Bill Taylor
limerick_list.text:
The limerick is poetry, terse,
Oft-rendered not better but worse
By rhymesters ham-fisted,
Their anapests twisted,
Whose doggerel is not worth a curse.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
A few items are traits of a plover,
	Which some birdwatchers long to discover,
	But a glance with a check
	For a ring 'round the neck,
	Will suffice for the dulwilly lover.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
As a necrophile, death is erotic;
My viewpoint most see as psychotic.
Sip this poison — one slurp'll
Turn you fetchingly purple.
I adore lovely lips cyanotic.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
The widow is heaving a sigh
And bereaving the loss of her guy.
I wonder, why is it
That fabric exquisite
Called black's what they wear when you die?

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
My phone's call history showed that I had
Not been talking that night to my dad,
Who was not at all thrilled
That our neighbour'd been killed,
So my alibi's blown—just too bad!

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
You can stretch a poetical line, (silent beat)
And your anapests still come out fine. (silent beat)
Standard limericks append
Silent beats at the end
Of lines 1, 2, and 5, just like mine. (silent beat)

limerick_list.author: DenmarK
limerick_list.text:
In calculus, delta's the rule:
Tiny steps make an elegant tool.
When parameters range,
You can find rate of change
With dy/dx — it's so cool!

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Esotericisms roll as I rant —
They're the insiders' jargon (or cant).
All those terms are obscure,
For I like to be sure
That dissent will be meagre (or scant).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I say "CINNamic," you say "cinnAMic"
About cakes on this plate of ceramic,
Or my cinnamon buns
(And of those I eat tons)—
Not my vinegar, that's called balsamic.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The chilopod fills me with fright.
I'm afraid of its poisonous bite.
The time I most dread?
When I get into bed,
As the chilopod's active at night.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
Old Man Winter had tightened his grip,
So I stopped at an inn for a flip:
A hot drink made with rum,
Ale, eggs, sugar, spice—yum!
A few sips will assuage that cold nip.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Your relationship therapist, Vic,
Wants your eyeballs impaled on a stick.
Ask him why, he'll reply,
"So you'll see eye-to-eye
When agreement's a difficult trick."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dust and splinters—debris in a storm,
From a building collapse—take the form
Of a rubble-filled cloud.
I've produced one—I'm proud—
Tearing down that enormous old dorm.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
'Mongst speakers of English are many who
Conclude every subject with "anyhoo",
Giving list'ners a clue
That the topic is through.
(Well, not everyone says it, but many do.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A courtier praises the queen,
Which induces Her Highness to preen.
Although flattery should
Get you nowhere, it's good
For a toady—in fact, it's routine.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Seven hours my soda had sat
In an uncovered can—that was that.
Lacking all carbonation
(That bubbly sensation),
Defizzed, now my Pepsi was flat.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"Sure, I haunt every Soho boutique;
I go clubbing: one has to be chic.
But I dine economically,"
She said, grinning comically,
"By eating just four times a week."

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
When you burn stuff, its oxides remain
In the air: gas (unseen) and smoke (plain).
Against smoke, greens are storming;
But the gas, acid-forming,
Without smoke will provoke acid rain.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Old Enceladus orbiting Saturn
Pukes up like a wine-sotted slattern.
Does he think it's benign,
Spewing geysers of brine
In an annulate vomity pattern?

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Judge, I dejerate (solemnly swear)
I'll stop dragging off babes by their hair.
Still, I've just gotta say
Some gals like it that way.
Bet I score more than you do—so there!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Let's consider the fetal circulation,
A convenient and clever creation.
Blood, from red to magenta,
Runs through the placenta,
Sustaining your child's maturation.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
So noble of bearing and regal
Is the famous American eagle.
This national treasure
Brings pride beyond measure—
So says an American beagle.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
Elena Hearty and limarico
limerick_list.text:
The bite was skin-deep when poor Fred
Was attacked by a monster undead.
Though it's now just cutaneal,
If the poison goes cranial
We'll have to shoot Fred in the head.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
I felt all my willpower slide.
I went to the doctor, who cried:
"Abulia, sir!
All my colleagues concur.
On the cause, though, we couldn't decide."

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
There was a young lady of Riga
Who went for a ride on a tiger.
Her counter tube said
That it ought to be dead…
Never put too much trust in a Geiger.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
Antiterrorist leaders are often
Campaigning for new ways to soften
The harmful effects
Of these terrorist sects,
So no voter ends up in a coffin.

limerick_list.author: Basingstoke
limerick_list.text:
My friend had a phobia fearful
Named anupta-. She called me, all tearful,
"I'll never be wed!"
Then she met her beau Fred,
And I now get a much diff'rent earful.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
In the tissue of folks in Brazil
Who had recently taken a spill,
Bradykinin was found.
Polypeptides abound
In this first vasodilator pill.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
When it rains, little Barbara stays jolly
In the shade and the shield of her brolly.
She will splish-splosh and twirl
While umbrella spokes whirl,
Nearly taking out eyes in her folly.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
At a rite where God surely is listening,
With the baptismal water a-glistening,
The babe gets his name;
Blessed Jesus lays claim
At the sacrament known as a christening.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Charged with speeding and hauled into court,
Werner Heisenberg's heard to retort,
"The police cannot prove
Where I was on the move
If they're sure of the speed they report."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Many critics in London you'll hear
Pan their own House of Lords with a sneer,
But the peers, when they fight
In the House, are polite;
It's a custom that won't disappear.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Agrigento's a town on the coast,
Where Sicilians live simply and boast
Of their ruins and beaches
And succulent peaches.
Agostina's the one I like most.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Though the IOC dinged us for doping,
Russian 'hacking teams' won't just be moping —
Super dupers are scooping
Covert medals for duping.
It's our banner-year, Vladimir's hoping.

limerick_list.author: Harris Risman
limerick_list.text:
The censoriousness of his sermon
Had his congregants nervously squirmin'.
"Don't arouse the Lord's ire,
Or you'll face hellish fire,"
Said a fierce evangelical German .  .  .

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
Normal matter is mostly what's left —
Was the baryogenesis... theft?
That's the term that explains
That the stuff that remains
Is of matter that's anti-, bereft.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I'll be faithful, my dear, I won't stray—
Let another guy lure me away.
But in truth, I must say
That another gal may;
Deep inside I suspect that I'm gay.

limerick_list.author: bestswanbird
limerick_list.text:
They took alcohol, morphine, cocaine;
Made a cocktail, "The Brompton", by name.
Sweet elixir of peace,
It brought rest and release,
And an end to the cancer's cruel pain.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Made of chocolate whipped softly with cream,
Their soft centres all taste like a dream.
Eat them up with panache,
Sweet chocs filled with ganache:
Tasty truffles to make eaters beam.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Court painter Francisco de Goya
Was one of Spain's finest. Enjoy a
Nude Maja (so fetching!),
A battle-themed etching,
Or mural of Saturn, destroyer.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
Mr Johnson, our prof, is okay,
But his thoughts tend to wander away.
Absent-mindedness hits
Sometimes, smashing to bits
All his plans for the lectures that day.

limerick_list.author: PdeG
limerick_list.text:
I can't think of anything cute
To say of the wax-myrtle's fruit.
As I don't know its taste
It won't add to my waist,
So the bayberry's value is moot.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
In the forest, a ranger is put
On alert, finding ashes and soot
At a camp where the bone
Of a deer has been thrown.
It's a hoof, so the game is afoot!

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
At the date palm of Deborah thrive
Wisdom, prophecy, judgment, as live
Swarms of honeybees bunk
In its honeycombed trunk:
Justice, gavel-less under a hive.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB and Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
I believe, but don't call me a mystic.
Toward God, my position's deistic—
He launched our affairs
But won't answer our prayers.
When I say so, my mom goes ballistic.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
You say hubby's too tired to do it?
Take this nightgown. Relax—nothin' to it!
Its diaphaneity
Will prompt spontaneity
And lust. Even blind men see through it!

limerick_list.author: Bit
limerick_list.text:
AC above 10,000 hertz
Is called d'Arsonval current. It skirts
Things like muscular twitching
Or feelings like itching 
That less fluctuation exerts.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
A bivvy bag (bivouac sack)
Takes the place of a tent in your pack
When you've mountains to climb,
But ain't wasting no time
Lugging canvas and poles on your back.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
With our store starting business today,
Our grand opening's set up to say
We've got bargains galore.
Plus you'll find many more:
There's a fire sale soon on its way.

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
The atto- reduces your unit
(From the Danish "eighteen" they have hewn it).
This quintillionth piece
Is no name of caprice;
It's quite useful, so don't you impugn it!

limerick_list.author: Kevin Dopart
limerick_list.text:
If you want to have fun you will find
That the Cat in the Hat is the kind
Of a book you should take,
But the Things in there make
A big mess that your mother would mind.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
We were shocked. A debilitating stroke
Left her voiceless, immobile and broke.
Is there hope? Not a trace;
Now she occupies space:
A young mother whose life's up in smoke.

limerick_list.author: Taillefer
limerick_list.text:
The seat of a bishop (or throne)
Can be wooden or made out of stone.
In times long gone by,
The chair of this guy
As a faldistory often was known.

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
Sure, we're thrilled you've got seven degrees,
And you're rich, and you've vast expertise,
And we'd love to hear more;
Carry on. (Just ignore
While we snore, as we're catching some Z's.)

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Some wee fairy's about; I can tell,
As the dairy's developed a smell.
If that fabulous fay
Has for too long held sway,
The whole larder will turn to his spell.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Two Jimmy's, a Johnny, a Bart,
Thad, Andy and Simon took part.
Tommy, Pete, Matt and Phil
Also followed Christ's will.
Hey Jude, you were bad from the start.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A baroreceptor's a cell
(Or a group of them) able to tell
That the pressure it senses
Has changed; it dispenses
A signal to neurons, as well.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
First Ben drives me away, then relents,
And he'll elegize, writing laments,
All so maudlinly mournful,
His poems seem scornful,
For Ben never truly repents.

limerick_list.author: kandabongo
limerick_list.text:
I awoke at the first crack of dawn,
Rubbed the sleep from my eyes, had a yawn,
When I noticed: that "crack"
Had seemed more like a "smack" . . .
Oh my god!  My truck flattened a fawn!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Capacify, scholars agree,
Means "to quality." How can that be?
For this odd definition,
I take the position
Confusion was clearly a key.

limerick_list.author: Bill LaVern Kalles
limerick_list.text:
Box end wrenches are closed all way 'round.
They fit tight on a nut, and I've found
Since they get a good grip
They're less likely to slip
(Unlike open end types) to the ground.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
One dermatopathology aim?
Find diseases physicians can tame.
If integument study
Impresses you, buddy,
You'll want to have skin in this game.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
It's oysters I eat by the panful
And spinach I down by the canful.
I can pop any tin
With my teeth and my chin.
So I am what I am, and that's manful.

limerick_list.author: snakelocks
limerick_list.text:
You point at my skin with a pin
Saying, "That's where this thing's going in."
But for those of my gender,
That acupoint's tender—
For treatment I'll stick with the gin.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
I fell for this car on the spot.
Should've bargained, of course; I could not.
She's so vivid and bright,
Bet she glows in the night.
My electric blue Mustang is hot.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
Pretty girls, whose enchanting "come hither"
Enticements send boys yon and thither,
Find none of that lasts.
Those who charmed in their pasts,
In decrepitude, find that they wither.

limerick_list.author: nevadaace
limerick_list.text:
The consultants declared at the start,
"We buy agency work à la carte.
One-stop marketers try
To do all.  That won't fly.
We let specialists deal with each part."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Definitionless? That's your complaint?
You declare that a good coat of paint
Would be justified here?
Let's be perfectly clear:
Other lims may be lame—this one ain't!

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Learning length units well takes a while.
Let's begin with the old English mile —
In kilometers? Fine,
One point six zero nine.
Awesome news for the circular file.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
You should always be sure to accredit
A statement when someone else said it.
Provide information
Re: its publication,
To give the appearance you've read it.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
DA-DA-BOOM! DA-DA-BOOM! DA-DA-BOOM!
Oh, my ears, when I step in your room!
Big low beats — I'm aghast
At the bass-heavy blast.
Turn it down! When I leave, then resume.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Had you fought like a man, you need not
Have been hanged like a dog." What a shot
To receive from one's wife
At the end of your life!
What is known of this gal? Not a lot.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Meet my butcher — my ham-handed crony;
Most times what he tells you is phony.
When he ventures his meat
Is the best ("Can't be beat!"),
Rest assured that he's full of baloney.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
On their vaginal voyage they're streamin',
And the winner must speed like a demon,
Analogous to
A superb vessel's crew:
Every sailor a true able seaman.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Grab your bunkers; they're right by your cot.
Where we're headed, it's bound to get hot.
They ain't comfy, they smell,
But I'm hearing that bell,
And in hell, man, we use what we've got.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
He writes eclogues, verse set in the leas,
 In which shepherds converse at their ease.
Unworldly? Perforce,
And bucolic, of course;
Read his eclogues. Start checking for fleas.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Bible-thumpers are short in supply.
"Trust the old-time religion!" they cry.
"Renounce sex, lust and sin!"
(But before I begin,
To be fair, I should give them a try!)

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
All the bassist's assistants filed cases,
Based on base and distasteful embraces,
Which hastened the bassist's
Erasing his traces
From places like cases and basses.

limerick_list.author: Charles Silliman
limerick_list.text:
The poor rhino, a mammal, cornific,
Has been hunted in numbers prolific.
People trust that the dust
Of ground horn fuels their lust;
It's a bust—not a bit scientific.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
What is cubane? No Cuban cigar,
Nor the bane of most Cubans, by far.
It's a molecule, box-
shaped, and chemists it shocks;
Hydrocarbons like these are bizarre.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Rather rough are these jokes on the ear;
They are best told by blokes drinking beer.
They're indelicate, rude,
And lasciviously lewd:
Dirty jokes aren't for prim folks to hear.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
My girl's father's a guy she calls Dad,
So a dad-in-law I could have had,
If the bloke hadn't told me
He was eager to scold me,
So the marriage was blown. Just too bad!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Single African well-read giraffe,
Likes to bowl, stands twelve feet and a half,
Seeks a mate, not uptight,
For hot necking at night.
Must have G.S.O.H. (love to laugh).

limerick_list.author: nevadaace and mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
After childbirth, consult your physician
If your babe's in an awful condition.
Aarskog syndrome's the name
Of the problems that came
From recessive genetic transmission.

limerick_list.author: Brent Annable
limerick_list.text:
"Here, I've brought them to show you," said Mabel,
Throwing hand-knitted socks on the table.
"See the part where it's curly,
All twisty and twirly?
My grandmother calls that a cable."

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Pininana's blue flowers compel,
As this Echium casts its tall spell.
On La Palma it's best,
Though in Britain's south west
It survives, though it's fussy as hell.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
That old freeloader Stu's on the bot,
Which puts Bruce in a stew, on the spot.
"Whatcha got, Bru, ya dag?
Wouldya bot me a fag?"
Will Bruce spot Stu a smoke? I think not.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
The young athlete was first off the block
But the runner was in for a shock.
Though she ran the race fast,
All the records will last ...
For no one had started the clock.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
My decision is fixed, final, firm:
You've no job at the end of this term.
Bio students complain
That you're slightly insane —
Not too much can be learned from one worm!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's a cheese with a base that's not lean,
And a name that's the oddest I've seen.
Care to guess what it's called?
Though one might be appalled,
It was named for a song played by Queen.

limerick_list.author: Kakuzan
limerick_list.text:
On the Coast, the banana can claim
To have lent an odd mollusk its name—
A slug of the redwoods
That nibbles on dead woods
Or plays in a Santa Cruz game.

limerick_list.author: Robert Holland
limerick_list.text:
In reruns, old Scotty will go
On and on beaming Kirk in a glow.
Though James Doohan is gone,
One fine day before dawn,
He'll beam back as the star of the show.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"I'm seducing this millionaire dame
For her money," he snickered. "For shame!"
I replied. "You had ought
Not be smug. You'll be caught!"
"I'm not worried. I'm using your name."

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Take an organism: has it a shell?
Does it live long, and where does it dwell?
Bioscientists find
That such knowledge combined
In life science explains every cell.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
You should really wear gloves on your hands
While you're batting; there're lots of good brands.
Let me give you a tip:
They will help with your grip—
That's the fifth bat you've thrown in the stands.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Will you dash off this note, short and sweet?
"Dear Soon Ex: While I'm working, you meet
With a guy, so we're through."
Send a copy then to
My attorney.  You care to go eat?

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Your claim is that you're my old flame,
But my memory's gone — what's your name?
Well, it's not that I doubt —
Guess I rubbed you right out.
You're erased, you effaceable dame.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
The anchorite friar appeared
In our town, with a long straggly beard.
He'd foresworn misbehaving,
Temptation, and shaving:
In need of a bath, but revered.

limerick_list.author: Jonathan M. Guberman
limerick_list.text:
A botanist taking a flight
Droned at length to the man on his right:
"Certain plants don't need air."
"Just shut up! I don't care."
'Twas an aero anaerophyte fight.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
If the feeling I'm feeling, my dove,
Isn't quite the same feeling as love,
You'll be willing, I trust,
To discover, in lust,
A contributive feature thereof.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
When out cross-country jumping, one´s steed
And oneself become one. As we speed
Over hedges and poles
We are two bonded souls,
Till one lands on one´s arse—guaranteed!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Scalpels must be much more than just clean,
Hence the dishwasher." "What does that mean?
Some hot water and soap
And a rinse cycle?" "Nope,
It's the sterilization machine."

limerick_list.author: Morphiend
limerick_list.text:
On our last Panthalassian cruise
There was shocking earth-shattering news.
Yep, Pangaea had split—
We were flummoxed a bit—
Then the crew had us forming two queues.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
"We've found DHMO in the seas.
All that coffee you drank, and cooked peas,
Had dihydromonoxide!"
Then, when this news shocks, I'd
Yell, "H2O!  April Fools' tease!"

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Bottom surgery isn't the kind
That augments or sucks fat from behind.
It's performed to surrender
Original gender:
The patient becomes reassigned.

limerick_list.author: geniuswaitress
limerick_list.text:
These old sixties comix you've found —
Don't read them when Mom is around.
They're drug-filled and crude,
And subversive and lewd
Which is why they were sold underground.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
A cabdriver (some call him hackie),
Addicted to brandy and baccy,
Once smashed up his hack
On a railway line track.
No wonder they thought he was wacky.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"This calendered paper is glossy,
As it's pressed by machine," stated Flossie.
"So it's hardly a wonder
That we use it down under
For posters we Aussies find saucy."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Bruce Willis, the actor who starred
In a series of films I regard,
Will save next, with his guns,
Senior-citizen nuns.
Working title: Old Habits Die Hard.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
Born a prince, he left all that behind;
'Neath a bodhi tree, freeing his mind,
He founded his teaching
And set about preaching
Great truths for all seekers to find.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Our anoles exhibit great keenery
To switch hues. Biologic machinery
Swaps dark brown for rich green;
It's routine when they preen.
Coloration helps blend with the greenery.

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
I take pride in my lexicon's size.
Up to date and informed, I despise
Any hip phrase or word
I don't know. This I heard:
Au courant — what the hell's that mean, guys?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
As a student of Latin, you face
On the blackboard: "Accusative case:
When a verb, in effect,
Makes an object direct."
This is info your mind will erase.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Had a strike at the chemistry lab:
Badly paid, and the workplace was drab.
Blacknob Bert had a smirk:
Would he still go to work?
Past the picket he went, what a scab!

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
What's an agger? I'll give you a guide:
Far and wide also called double tide.
It could climb and then fall,
Then rise over the wall—
Or go down, rise a bit, then subside.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
'Neath the radar he preached war and hate,
Unnoticed by most 'til too late.
No, it didn't take long;
Out of view, he grew strong.
We now live in that dictator's state.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
They used to build ships for the king.
In exchange he allowed them to bring
Foreign goods of all sorts
To the land of Cinque Ports;
As for taxes—they meant not a thing.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
You have anabohitsite in stock?
This pyroxenite-olivine rock
Will become my new pet—
A possession I'm set
To appreciate, pamper, and grok.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Chris, your x-rays reveal something strange,"
Said my doctor. "You need to arrange
For a surgeon and shrink—
There's within you, I think,
At least twenty-five dollars in change."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Disslanderous? Well, it's like this:
As my father once said to me, "Chris,
It means 'slanderous,' yes?
And that first d-i-s
Just implies it's for people we dis."

limerick_list.author: Wordmatic
limerick_list.text:
Humidity's out. So are lights,
Not to mention flash cameras, most nights.
And it wouldn't be smart
To touch paintings—our art
Conservator's given to fights.

limerick_list.author: Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
Early August 216 B.C.
Showed the Romans how weak they could be.
Having lost twice before,
They helped Hannibal's score
Grow from "two battles won" up to "three".

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
Ascertainment here's never for sure
When both meter and rhyme are obscure,
But by doing this right,
Then perhaps I just might
Write a limerick that's sure to endure.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
To patients, with temperature high,
Said doctors, in days long gone by:
"The fevers that plague you
Suggest that the ague
Has visited you, I descry."

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
Crikey, don't chuck a wobbly there, Kit.
Hey, I'm sorry—don't throw such a fit.
That's what Aussies would say
If you ranted that way—
'Sides, it sure makes you look like a git!

limerick_list.author: cilliantsu
limerick_list.text:
No savory, spicy, or sweet,
No salad, potatoes or meat.
My tum sorely rumbles;
My blood sugar tumbles.
I'm foodless: I've nothing to eat.

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
Zeke, do not be dismayed by the glint
In their impudent faces. By dint
Of the roll that you ate
I have rendered your pate
As an adamant harder than flint.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Billy Butlin was head of a chain
Of large holiday camps. In the main
They were built by the sea,
Where we all like to be
And would go to again and again.

limerick_list.author: Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
In the Cold War, the West states would mock:
"Eastern Europe's not free—what a crock."
They were ruled from afar
By the USSR
As a part of the Communist Bloc.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
My girlfriend loves pickles and fries,
And garlic with kippers in pies.
Her rank halitosis
Has caused this chemosis;
Her breath's bringing tears to my eyes.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In the hull of this ship, compartmentation
Means "dividing it up." Motivation?
To keep most of it dry.
Should some water sneak by,
It will limit the liquid's migration.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
It's been windy; the lake water's rough.
I feel sick. This one's gonna be tough.
I've been rowing nonstop,
But I can't fight the chop.
About now, any landing's enough.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Game of flats. See the lads.  Chew the fat.
Staked the lot on four queens (yes!) but that
Was pipped (NO!) by four kings.
Lost my flat, all my things,
And so that's why I'm feeling so flat.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Be a frogman," they said. "You can do it!"
Though the training was tough, I got through it.
Now a wet suit I don
And two air tanks put on
For my job. Wanna join me? Jump to it!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
To dinner my dad asked his boss.
Where to seat him? My mom's at a loss.
At the head of the table?
Next to Sid, who's unstable?
Not with Sid! No, diagonally across.

limerick_list.author: Kim Le
limerick_list.text:
His brutishness made her feel wanted—
She yearned for him; still, she was haunted.
For she'd say, "You're a pig!"
And he'd snap like a twig;
Beat her senseless whene'er he felt taunted.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I'm a great filler finder, I am.
I have just passed my Master's exam!
Useless words I embrace;
I just drop them in place
Cause I don't give a …hmm… tinker's damn!

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Skip the primer? No way. I maintain
That extractives would leach and show stain
On this new wooden siding.
For permanent hiding,
Prime well—or paint over again.

limerick_list.author: Robert Schechter
limerick_list.text:
Eden, for those who still cleave
To the Bible, means "garden where Eve
And Adam once dwelled
Before being compelled,
For eating an apple, to leave."

limerick_list.author: danmcgrath
limerick_list.text:
At Trafalgar, Lord Nelson was bold —
Cut the French line of battle, we're told.
But while walking his deck,
Caught a slug in the neck.
Now he's dead, on his column, and cold.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
You're a daydreamer, dear, and it's clear
The professors do not have your ear.
You hear nothing they say,
As you're far, far away—
In your mind, you've gone out for a beer.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
On a path getting swervish and curvish,
An oncoming whirligig dervish
Keeps spinning and twirling
And soon could be hurling.
This calender's making me nervish.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
For our home, we don't use the word doors.
We say "entryways," grander than yours:
Double-wide, solid oak—
Lord, she's spending me broke—
Next, Carrara instead of mere floors.

limerick_list.author: timon
limerick_list.text:
This rug (though its colours are harsh)
Is a good one; you see the abrash?
That's the varying range
Of the dyes' colour change
As they age (like my greying moustache).

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Some geologists, earning big salaries
For their work in geology galleries,
Know that crocolite is,
In the mineral biz,
Not some gator that's famed for less calories.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Of what am I being accused?
You rant, with your visage suffused,
"You deserve to be parboiled!"
I find myself garboiled —
Agitated, disturbed, and confused.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
After golf, twee McTavish's daddy
Lavished flowers and tea on his caddy.
China roses looked great,
But the brew was served late:
"Chai na rose to the boiling point, laddie."

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
I'm so tall that you may hear a rumor
It's gigantism, caused by a tumor.
Ask my five-foot-two wife:
It's a difficult life,
Not a suitable topic for humor.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
There's a musical statement I know
Called a break strain, that ruptures the flow
Of a march or a rag.
It's a battle-sound flag
That for war tunes is most apropos.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
A boastful, old farmer called Woods
Bragged his rooster was king of the studs.
Let the two of them crow—
We, the egg lovers, know
It's the hens that deliver the goods.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
I live in what's called the "Big Smoke"
With non-rural and citified folk.
We're tough and we're gritty
And love the big city,
And will til the day that we croak.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
All your strutting and fanfaronade
Is so bogus—a vulgar façade.
How you posture and crow!
Why the girls buy your show
Is a puzzlement, honest to God.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
In the bathroom, perhaps in the nude,
Where your focus is totally glued
On the task now in hand,
Grip your tube, as you planned:
Squeeze it hard and your paste will extrude.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Little balls of chopped liver he bound
Up with herbs, then wrapped bread all around.
And when oven-cooked slowly,
Although sounding lowly,
His faggots were tasty, he found.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
On my charger, I'll certainly gallop on
Till I reach my estate, and I shall upon
Coming home to my fields,
Boost my sugarcane yields
With the help of the herbicide dalapon.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I have seen with my own naked eye—
This I swear, cross my heart, hope to die—
What? A dragon for real!
Come outside; here's the deal:
See? There's Draco—way up in the sky.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown and SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Like the claws of a fierce bird of prey,
The thing clung to his nose that sad day.
The accipiter's shield
Helped his schnoz till it healed,
Though he looked pretty weird, truth to say.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
My angel-stars' blossoms are droopy;
